          • EchoChaos says:
            August 15, 2019 at 6:58 am

            @viVI_IViv

            How so?

            Japanese-Americans were only excluded from certain militarily critical zones. They were free to just relocate to another part of the country and many did. But some preferred to wait in the camps until the war ended.

          • Conrad Honcho says:
            August 15, 2019 at 7:09 am

            What EchoChaos said. They weren’t prison camps, so they wouldn’t need to kill anybody in order to leave. They might need to kill somebody to go back to the west coast if they didn’t get special permission, but they could also just move to Ohio. About 25% did.

            ETA: I’m not saying it was good, I’m just saying it wasn’t totalitarian enough to justify murder.

          • viVI_IViv says:
            August 15, 2019 at 7:18 am

            Japanese-Americans were only excluded from certain militarily critical zones. They were free to just relocate to another part of the country and many did. But some preferred to wait in the camps until the war ended.

            The “military critical zones” consisted in most of the West coast, where the wast majority of Japanese-Americans lived.

            From Wikipedia:

            “March 2, 1942: Lieutenant General John L. DeWitt issued Public Proclamation No. 1, declaring that “such person or classes of persons as the situation may require” would, at some later point, be subject to exclusion orders from “Military Area No. 1” (essentially, most of California, Oregon, and Washington to about 100.2 miles (161.3 km) inland), and requiring anyone who had “enemy” ancestry to file a Change of Residence Notice if they planned to move.[18] A second exclusion zone was designated several months later which included the areas chosen by most of the Japanese Americans who had managed to leave the first zone.
            March 11, 1942: Executive Order 9095 created the Office of the Alien Property Custodian, and gave it discretionary, plenary authority over all alien property interests. Many assets were frozen, creating immediate financial difficulty for the affected aliens, preventing most from moving out of the exclusion zones.[18]”

            So their assets were seized and they were given the option to either relocate hundreds of miles away, with no means to support themselves, or be interned in a government camp. Sounds exactly like the sort of dystopian government infringement of personal liberties that private gun ownership is supposed to prevent according to gun rights supporters.

          • baconbits9 says:
            August 15, 2019 at 7:40 am

            They tried and succeeded.

            This link doesn’t support the statement. From the wikipedia numbers ~11,000 germans were interred out of 1.2 million native born germans living in the US, so ~1% of all native born germans and ~0.2% of all native born germans + US born to two native born german parents. The US government made no effort to round up every, most or really even some german born residents.

          • baconbits9 says:
            August 15, 2019 at 7:43 am

            So their assets were seized and they were given the option to either relocate hundreds of miles away, with no means to support themselves, or be interned in a government camp. Sounds exactly like the sort of dystopian government infringement of personal liberties that private gun ownership is supposed to prevent according to gun rights supporters.

            You are apparently unfamiliar with what EXACTLY dystopian governments do, and are building a strawman as to how effective a tiny fraction of the population could reasonably be.

          • Hoopyfreud says:
            August 15, 2019 at 7:45 am

            @Conrad, Echo

            Didn’t we go over this last time? The Congressional commission found that people could not “just leave” the camps. Because of pressure from the states the Japanese Americans were imprisoned in, they weren’t allowed to just walk out of the camps and compete with their fellow Americans. To leave you had to have a job offer and wait for the relocation authority to approve you as a non-risk. To get a job offer your employer had to be sure you’d be able to work for them. This meant that leaving was difficult to impossible for a lot of people – especially, and perversely, for families.

          • Conrad Honcho says:
            August 15, 2019 at 7:49 am

            No, I seem to recall that we tried to find out the process for leaving the camps and could not. All we know is that 25% of them managed to do it.

            It seems like it involves some phone calls and paperwork, maybe? I don’t think that’s worth killing over.

            We all agree if the Jews had been able to, we would prefer an alternate history in which they used guns and killed the nazis rather than be placed in the concentration camps, correct? It’s a tragedy of history that they were unable to.

            Was it a tragedy of history that the Japanese Americans did not secure guns and kill the Americans who took them to the internment camps?

          • Hoopyfreud says:
            August 15, 2019 at 8:55 am

            @Conrad

            Echo said:

            They were free to just relocate to another part of the country and many did. But some preferred to wait in the camps until the war ended.

            And you said:

            Why would they need to fight when they could just, ya know, leave the camp…

            Unless you believe that the commission was lying about the ease of leaving the camps, and actually 75% of Japanese Americans preferred living in uninsulated shacks for years, that’s a new and interesting definition of the word “could,” in the same way that “can” is in the sentence, “any American can own a machine gun.”

            As for the question of whether Americans should defend themselves by force when the government rounds them up in camps… I dunno man. It doesn’t seem that unreasonable to me. Would the world be a better place if we’d had an actual armed Japanese American insurrection in the middle of WWII? Maybe not. It would have made the whole thing harder to heal and entrenched the racism that motivated the internment in the first place*. But I wouldn’t be able to look someone who lost a child to tuberculosis in the camps in the eye and tell them that wasn’t a thing worth fighting to prevent. Or even someone who, like a majority of internees, “only” lost their home.

            *: If you want to argue about this I’m willing to, but it’s fairly well-substantiated that the majority of Japanese Americans posed no threat, and that the US Government knew that.

          • Conrad Honcho says:
            August 15, 2019 at 9:04 am

            I’m not really interested in a pedantic argument over whether “can” means “can easily” or “can with great effort.”

            Also I don’t think anyone, even anyone at the time, claimed any significant number of JA were a threat. If they had been they wouldn’t have been allowed out at all. The claim was that the damage from even one could be immense.

            Everybody wants to talk about rights and nobody wants to talk about responsibilities. Total war is total war. Sometimes during total war the government comes to you and says “hey you, take this gun, get on this boat going halfway around the world and kill some people, and maybe try not to get killed yourself.” Sometimes during total war the government comes to you and says “hey you, we can’t be sure you’re not a bad guy, so howsabout you stay away from this area for a few years?” Maybe we all ought to just do our duty for the war effort for a few years and not get so hung up about the rights thing that we lose the war, and with it all of our rights, eh?

          • Hoopyfreud says:
            August 15, 2019 at 10:20 am

            Everybody wants to talk about rights and nobody wants to talk about responsibilities.

            But the Japanese incarceration wasn’t necessary, as determined by the US prior to the incarceration! And fuck, it’s not like the Japanese were making landings on American soil. There was no evidence of espionage or sabotage to go on. Even if DeWitt was right, and “an exact separation of the ‘sheep from the goats’ was unfeasible,” that doesn’t make it OK. It undermines the identity of the nation and makes a mockery of its foundational principles.

            If the US somehow ended up in total war with a China-backed Mexico tomorrow (for the sake of the hypothetical), would you really be OK with rounding up 35 million Americans? That’s more than the population of Texas. There’s nowhere to put them. The only alternatives available at that point are admitting that ancestry isn’t a great determinant of allegiance or giving them a bullet. The fact that the Japanese American population was small enough in the 1940s for a third option to feasibly be administered doesn’t excuse the underlying calculus; either an unacceptable operational risk exists or it doesn’t.

          • Conrad Honcho says:
            August 15, 2019 at 10:25 am

            But the Japanese incarceration wasn’t necessary, as determined by the US prior to the incarceration!

            Why did they do it then? This does not make sense.

          • thisheavenlyconjugation says:
            August 15, 2019 at 10:47 am

            The US government made no effort to round up every, most or really even some german born residents.

            They quite clearly did round up some German residents — specifically 11,000 of them. I never claimed all Germans were interned, since that is clearly not true. My point is that, contra cassander, the US government intern *some* Germans (I’m assuming the Texan qualification is tangential) without creating a political storm.

          • Hoopyfreud says:
            August 15, 2019 at 11:04 am

            Why did they do it then?

            Gee I wonder.

            The US was scared. Japanese Americans looked foreign and kept different customs. Is it really so mysterious?

            Look at the Ringle report. Note the date.

            https://www.history.navy.mil/research/library/online-reading-room/title-list-alphabetically/r/ringle-report-on-japanese-internment.html

          • Paul Brinkley says:
            August 15, 2019 at 3:05 pm

            Look at the Ringle report. Note the date. [The] Japanese incarceration wasn’t necessary, as determined by the US prior to the incarceration!

            I couldn’t get that site to load, but in the process of looking for other documentation, I ran across the Niihau Incident again:

            Historian Gordon Prange notes that it was “the rapidity with which the three resident Japanese went over to the pilot’s cause” which troubled the Hawaiians. “The more pessimistic among them cited the Niihau incident as proof that no one could trust any Japanese, even if an American citizen, not to go over to Japan if it appeared expedient.”

            Does the Ringle report address this? Niihau happened in Dec 1941; the last Ringle report was in June 1942.

          • Hoopyfreud says:
            August 15, 2019 at 3:27 pm

            @Paul

            I believe it preceded the Niihau incident, but it did state:

            there are among the Japanese both alien and United States citizens, certain individuals, either deliberately placed by the Japanese government or actuated by a fanatical loyalty to that country who would act as saboteurs or agents. This number is estimated to be less than three per cent of the total, or about 300 in the entire United States.

            The central question is not whether these people existed, but whether their existence warranted the imprisonment and impoverishment of 80,000 Americans (and 40,000 of their parents, made ineligible for citizenship by their race).

          • sentientbeings says:
            August 15, 2019 at 5:16 pm

            @thisheavenlyconjugation

            (I’m assuming the Texan qualification is tangential)

            Why would you assume that? It seemed clear to me that it was very much an intentional qualification, germane to the point.

          • Conrad Honcho says:
            August 16, 2019 at 5:26 am

            @Hoopyfreud

            The central question is not whether these people existed, but whether their existence warranted the imprisonment and impoverishment of 80,000 Americans (and 40,000 of their parents, made ineligible for citizenship by their race).

            And the answer is “you don’t know, but it doesn’t stop you from reaching into the past to assert your moral superiority over the dead with no skin in the game.” There were also about 5,000 Japanese Americans who renounced their citizenship. How many more were there who did so in their hearts but not officially? In the counterfactual world where President Hoopyfreud prosecuted the war, how many lives would be lost and how much longer would the war have gone on due to sabotage and espionage from the subset of Japanese Americans we know to have been disloyal?

            I’m wary of proclamations wherein I get to assert my moral superiority over people long dead, who cannot defend themselves, who were making difficult choices with imperfect information without the benefit of hindsight in the most strenuous times imaginable all the while risking no possibility of negative outcomes for myself. It seems a little too easy and self-serving. But you are a bolder and obviously better man than I or FDR.

          • Hoopyfreud says:
            August 16, 2019 at 10:21 am

            But you are a bolder and obviously better man than I or FDR.

            You know what? Sure. I’ll bite that bullet. Reagan, HW Bush, and Clinton did. The information available did not justify the internment, and FDR should have known better.

          • cassander says:
            August 16, 2019 at 2:48 pm

            @thisheavenlyconjugation

            (I’m assuming the Texan qualification is tangential)

            The qualification is important because am assuming that texan germans were ornerier and better armed than the average german in the US, and much more so than the average Japanese. This might not be born our by the facts, but if it’s not, there must be some immigrant community that fits the bill, feel free to substitute them instead.

          • thisheavenlyconjugation says:
            August 17, 2019 at 4:53 am

            @cassander
            Assume for the sake of argument that none of the interned Germans were Texan. Then your claim is not that guns prevent tyranny, but that a very specific culture does. You could reasonably argue that Japanese-Americans are an exception to a general American anti-tyranny culture, but if you’re now restricting that culture to specific groups within one state then the argument in favour of gun ownership (outside of Texas at least) is greatly weakened.

          • cassander says:
            August 17, 2019 at 7:44 am

            @themthisheavenlyconjugation says:

            Assume for the sake of argument that none of the interned Germans were Texan. Then your claim is not that guns prevent tyranny, but that a very specific culture does.

            what is accomplishing the goal here is possession of the guns and the willingness to use them. Sure, some cultures are more likely to buy guns and more eager to use them, but the culture on its own accomplishes very little if it doesn’t also have the guns.

          • thisheavenlyconjugation says:
            August 17, 2019 at 9:12 am

            @cassander
            People usually make the argument “guns prevent tyranny” rather than “guns and a culture similar to that of Texas prevent tyranny”. If you’re making the latter then that’s commendable in my book but unusual. And it also concedes quite a lot. For instance, if you want to defend gun rights in Washington or California you now need a different argument.

          • cassander says:
            August 17, 2019 at 2:03 pm

            @thisheavenlyconjugation says:

            People usually make the argument “guns prevent tyranny” rather than “guns and a culture similar to that of Texas prevent tyranny”. If you’re making the latter then that’s commendable in my book but unusual. And it also concedes quite a lot. For instance, if you want to defend gun rights in Washington or California you now need a different argument.

            Again, culture prevents nothing on its own. Guns + willingness to use them can prevent things. But it should be beyond obvious that a place that has no guns certainly isn’t going to develop a culture that’s willing to use them, so the guns themselves remain a necessary precondition.

          • thisheavenlyconjugation says:
            August 17, 2019 at 2:42 pm

            You’re not engaging with my point.

            so the guns themselves remain a necessary precondition

            I’m not disagreeing with this. I’m saying that your implied argument of “we should allow Californians to own guns so that it’s possible that at some point in the future they could develop a culture that (when combined with possession of said guns) might enable them to resist tyranny” is a lot weaker than the usual argument “we should allow Californians to own guns so that they are able to resist tyranny”.

        • AlesZiegler says:
          August 15, 2019 at 6:44 am

          I´d like to point out that shortage of commoners with guns wasn´t exactly a problem in 1917 Russia. Not sure about Weimar Germany. But yes, if in CONTEMPORARY society governments will try to ship commoners into gulags, you Americans will be in far better position than us Europeans in terms of ability to resist that. Until then it is however perfectly possible to enjoy free society without constitutional right to gun ownership.

          • viVI_IViv says:
            August 15, 2019 at 6:58 am

            Not sure about Weimar Germany.

            The Weimar Republic had quite restrictive gun ownership laws right after WW1, at least on paper, as they had to have in order to comply with the Treaty of Versailles. The laws were progressively relaxed before the Nazi took over, then the Nazi further relaxed the laws, except for the Jews.

          • DeWitt says:
            August 15, 2019 at 8:20 am

            at least on paper

            This part is doing a hell of a lot of heavy lifting, given the amount of paramilitary violence the republic had going on.

          • albatross11 says:
            August 15, 2019 at 8:38 am

            The widespread use of no-knock midnight raids in the US seems like a much stronger case that widespread gun ownership doesn’t prevent tyranny.

          • AlexOfUrals says:
            August 15, 2019 at 11:41 am

            shortage of commoners with guns wasn´t exactly a problem in 1917 Russia

            Nor, in fact, were the gulags. The Soviet government started to limit private ownership of guns as soon as 1918, and by 1924 people not in service were only allowed to have smooth barrel hunting guns. First gulags were created in 1929 and they fully ramped up in early 30s.

            Not that there were no repressions before that, of course, but seems like even if you’re early Soviet Union, you still prefer to take guns from people before starting to execute and enslave them massively.

          • AlesZiegler says:
            August 15, 2019 at 2:16 pm

            @AlexOfUrals

            Thing is, many Russian citizens did rose up in armed revolt against encroaching tyranny, but were defeated and many of them massacred in Russian Civil War by other armed Russian citizens enthusiastically supporting said tyranny. And victorious Bolsheviks then proceeded to disarm the population.

            Russian Revolution isn´t encouraging example for proponents of the theory that armed population is check against tyranny, since Bolshevik takeover was greatly facilitated by mass arming of large fraction of Russian commoners, aka mobilization for world war, and tyranny was instituted from bottom up by this armed mob, which got out of control of the government.

          • AlexOfUrals says:
            August 15, 2019 at 9:50 pm

            @AlesZiegler
            Agreed, that’s more or less what’s happened, but I don’t think it’s an argument against guns. Less guns in the hands of common people would’ve made any kind of a revolution less likely, regardless of the ideology. In the alternative world where Russian peasants and workers of the time were less fond of communism, and more of say liberal democracy, they would’ve been just as much helped by having guns, or hindered by not having. Unless you argue that any violent change of government is a bad thing no matter what, the Russian revolution isn’t actually very relevant to gun control, I think.

            You can interpret it as a weak pro-gun evidence (armed populace worked as intended and changed government, it’s not guns to blame that said populace happened to have some stupid ideas) or as neutral (the revolution didn’t depend strongly on the armed populace and would’ve happened anyway) but it’s hard to see how this is an anti-gun example.

      • The Nybbler says:
        August 15, 2019 at 8:23 am

        Here in the US, there’s a long history — still going on — of abusing such requirements. New Jersey requires you to list name and location any doctor or psychiatrist who has ever seen you for any mental health condition in your entire life. What, you’re 50 years old and you don’t have records for someone you might have seen when you were 14? Sorry, no gun for you. If you just do your best, you’ve committed a strict liability offense.

        • AlesZiegler says:
          August 15, 2019 at 8:52 am

          This is a good point. Poor quality of governance mechanisms on the level of States of the US could absolutely lead to awful implementation.

        • Lillian says:
          August 15, 2019 at 11:08 am

          Ugh, strict liability offenses in criminal law is such an abomination unto justice. For torts it can be useful and necessary, but in criminal law nothing more serious than a moving violation should ever be strict liability.

      • hash872 says:

      • Lillian says:

This is a country where heavily armed and armoured police forces regularly terrorize people in their own homes for merely being suspected of having the wrong kind of plant. Sometimes they get the wrong address and fucking kill an innocent person and still suffer no consequences. So you’re going to have to excuse me if i am extremely reluctant to give these people any more power whatsoever.

          • AlesZiegler says:

          • Machine Interface says:
            August 15, 2019 at 3:01 pm

            The critical difference is that in Switzerland, “gun owner” means “I have a military rifle safely locked in a cupboard at home”. It’s almost impossible to get a carry permit in Switzerland, and iirc handguns are rare.

          • LesHapablap says:
            August 15, 2019 at 3:02 pm

            I think it is the law enforcement training and culture to treat the populace that way. Actual shooting deaths of police are incredibly rare, 52 in 2018 out of ~800,000 police officers. For reference, the rest of the US population overall homicide rate is ~5 per 100,000. So police work is only slightly more dangerous than just regular life.

          • sentientbeings says:
            August 15, 2019 at 5:30 pm

            Nonsense.

            Police militarization and trigger happy behavior is primarily a product of the drug war, with honorable mentions going to the War on Terror and certain legal rules related to police liability.

            You can look at the historical timeline of spending, what equipment they have, policies they institute (especially regarding training), etc. and it matches up.

            Americans have always been armed. Police abuse has, naturally, been around a while as well, but militarization and the abuse of qualified immunity are more recent phenomena, and they have nothing to do with citizens’ right to own firearms.

          • Douglas Knight says:
            August 15, 2019 at 8:33 pm

            According to gunpolicy.org, 10% of Swiss households have a handgun, compared to 20% of American households. 40% of American households have a firearm, compared to 30% of Swiss households (supposedly restricting to civilian arms).

          • Conrad Honcho says:
            August 16, 2019 at 5:54 am

            Rookie numbers.

          • Lillian says:
            August 16, 2019 at 8:50 pm

            Gun ownership rates in the United States has been going down for decades while police militarization has been steadily increasing as documented by the evolution of the Lego policeman. In 1969 your typical police officer was much more likely to encounter an armed person, especially in an urban area, than they are in 2019. Yet in 1969 your typical police officer was much less willing to conduct what can only be called a raid on someone’s home in order to execute a search warrant. Instead they would knock on the door, present their warrant, and ask to be let inside. You know, like civilized officers of the law instead of like a hostile occupying army.

            To put some numbers on this, according to Wikipedia, “The number of no-knock raids has increased from 3,000 in 1981 to more than 50,000 in 2005, according to Peter Kraska, a criminologist at Eastern Kentucky University in Richmond. Raids that lead to deaths of innocent people are increasingly common; since the early 1980s, forty bystanders have been killed, according to the Cato Institute in Washington, D.C. In Utah, no-knock warrants make up about 40% of all warrants served. In Maryland, 90% of SWAT deployments were to serve search warrants, with two-thirds through forced entry.”

            Again this has been a period in which people have become less armed and policing has become less dangerous. This graph actually understates the case since it gives raw numbers of police deaths, despite the sizes of active police increasing in the intervening time.

            In short, no i don’t think civilian gun ownership is to blame.

          • Nick says:
            August 16, 2019 at 9:09 pm

            @Lillian
            Now I want an accompanying image of armed Lego citizens captioned “Don’t tread on me.”

    • Conrad Honcho says:
      August 15, 2019 at 6:42 am

      But- in the interest of fairness, it did occur to me that we already have involuntary commitment laws for those who are a danger to themselves, or others.

      That is far more often done for “danger to themselves” because they’re threatening suicide. Or they’re bipolar and entering a manic phase. So there is not necessarily the expectation of violence when the police go to collect this person, and they may or may not be armed. With “red flag” gun control they’re only showing up because they believe a person known to be armed is about to get violent. There’s different types of crazy.

      Oh, and what will actually happen is nothing. Absolutely nothing. No new laws will be passed because of any of this. Also Trump needs to shut up about vidya games.

    • albatross11 says:
      August 15, 2019 at 8:00 am

      What’s the false positive rate? (That is, how often does someone raise a red flag who wasn’t going to do anything bad?). Any way of detecting some bad thing has a false-positive rate. And when the thing you’re actually looking for is extremely rare, the false positive

      For simplicity, suppose one person in a million is going to become a mass-shooter, and that our red flags have a false-positive rate of one in a thousand[1]. The result is that for every mass-shooter we stop, we also involuntarily commit or otherwise deprive of their civil rights *a thousand* innocent people. This would almost certainly do more harm than good.

      [1] They will probably be a lot worse than that.

      • viVI_IViv says:
        August 15, 2019 at 8:18 am

        For simplicity, suppose one person in a million is going to become a mass-shooter, and that our red flags have a false-positive rate of one in a thousand[1]. The result is that for every mass-shooter we stop, we also involuntarily commit or otherwise deprive of their civil rights *a thousand* innocent people. This would almost certainly do more harm than good.

        But if one mass-shooter kills an average of, say, 20 people, then for every person you save you deprive 50 people of their rights to own guns. Your mileage may vary, but it doesn’t look like an obviously bad deal.

        • albatross11 says:
          August 15, 2019 at 8:32 am

          I think if you want to propose some kind of precrime / red flag scheme, you need to surface that tradeoff. For every one mass-shooting prevented, you have N cases of collateral damage to people who weren’t going to do anything.

          I also think that:

          a. It’s pretty unlikely the only consequence of tripping a red flag would be not being allowed to buy a gun. I’d imagine at the very least, this would also involve having the police search your house for weapons (and arrest you if they find anything they think is suspicious), check your social media and internet activity for indications of a threat, and having you under a certain amount of continuing surveillance. Probably every time a policeman runs your license plate number, he’ll get the red flag alert. This may also come up w.r.t. allowing you to keep coming to school, child custody cases, etc.

          b. How serious a civil rights violation it is to deprive you of the right to buy a gun is one of the things that divides people about this issue. Plenty of people think nobody should have a gun unless they’ve got a really good reason; they think depriving you of this right is basically free. Others think it’s a fundamental constitutional right on a par with freedom of speech, and depriving you of it is a serious matter that should require some kind of actual crime.

          • Conrad Honcho says:
            August 15, 2019 at 8:40 am

            This may also come up w.r.t. allowing you to keep coming to school, child custody cases, etc.

            That’s a very good point. We’ve already had calls to ban people on the no-fly list from buying a gun. It seems like once you’ve got a list of “Official Maybe Bad Guys” for the purpose of denying them X, people are going to want to use that list to deny them Y and Z, too.

            Do you want to work with someone who’s been Red Flagged? Should HR be checking with the Red Flag list before hiring somebody? “Private companies can do whatever they want!” after all.

        August 15, 2019 at 8:44 am

        Well that, and I’d really love to hear from an actual mental health professional the ins and outs of the ‘involuntary commitment for safety reasons’ process that we already have

    • John Schilling says:
      August 15, 2019 at 4:01 pm

      Depending on exactly how these are implemented, the dominant effect of “red flag” laws will probably be:

      A. Gun owners, and especially red tribe “deplorable” gun owners or marginalized-loner gun owners, will be much less likely to seek treatment for mental health issues due to the fear that they will be red-flagged by some blue-tribe psychiatrist, or

      B. An uptick in domestic violence against family members (mostly women) who called in a red flag against one of their family, who is now pissed and wants payback and doesn’t actually need a gun to abuse or kill someone who sleeps in the same house, or

      C. Both, but the proponents will still be happy with what they see as a stepping stone towards broadly confiscatory gun control.

      Anecdotally, I believe we’re already seeing an element of A among veterans.

      • Matt M says:
        August 16, 2019 at 6:17 am

        I used to work with reservists returning from mobilization and we are definitely already seeing a whole lot of A. They are terrified of admitting anything remotely resembling PTSD, lest they get kicked out of the military and have their guns taken away. It often doesn’t end well.

        • EchoChaos says:
          August 16, 2019 at 6:23 am

          Absolutely. Permanently losing a right because of this is a massive problem and leads to undertreatment amongst a vulnerable class.

        • The Nybbler says:
          August 16, 2019 at 9:47 am

          No stigma for mental health treatment

          Proactive protection of society from the dangerously mentally ill.

          Pick one, no more. And no, treating everyone as if they are dangerously mentally ill doesn’t work. Not even for gun control; some people have to be cops and in the military, after all.

          • DinoNerd says:
            August 16, 2019 at 10:04 am

            The problem, of course, is that no distinction is made about type or severity of mental illnesses.

            An equivalent would be banning people with allergies from the workplace, lest they share their dangerous illness. (Physical illnesses are mostly spread by germs, and some such illnesses can be fatal, maybe even with antibiotics, thanks to antibiotic resistance. If we can’t or won’t distinguish between physical illnesses, then people with asthma might give you a fatal disease – like the cancer your cousin died of.)

          • John Schilling says:
            August 16, 2019 at 3:20 pm

            The problem, of course, is that no distinction is made about type or severity of mental illnesses.

            This. To far too many Americans, including American legislators, any formal diagnosis of mental illness or even a three-day hold to see if someone might be mentally ill, is by a warped application of the precautionary principle treated as indicating a person is an incurable homicidal maniac or close enough as makes no difference.

            f we can’t or won’t distinguish between physical illnesses, then people with asthma might give you a fatal disease – like the cancer your cousin died of.)

            And therefore a person who coughs or sneezes in public might need to be locked away in quarantine, and a person who calls in sick to work definitely needs to be locked away in quarantine. Now consider the behavior of people who aren’t immune to the common cold but don’t want to be quarantined, and despair for your ability to stop e.g. flu epidemics.

    • littleby says:
      August 16, 2019 at 6:28 pm

      Reminds me of the recent news article about Justin Olsen. Apparently he posted the instruction “Shoot every federal agent on sight”; he also posted a meme of a guy shooting guns, with the caption “me walking into the nearest planned parenthood”. Then he got arrested for threatening a federal agent. They took around 25 guns from his home.

      It sounds like you think red flag laws would be applied to “loners/misfits/weirdos”, and you’re opposed to that. Do you also think red flag laws should not be applied to people like Justin Olsen, who post threats of terrorism in online forums?

      If we had a way to restrict these laws to people who had made actual death threats, would you be in favor of them then?

      • Nornagest says:
        August 16, 2019 at 6:38 pm

        Making a death threat is already a felony. Meaning that it already disqualifies anyone doing it from owning a firearm.

        • littleby says:
          August 16, 2019 at 7:50 pm

          I have the sense that this law isn’t very well enforced?

          Like, apparently people make death threats on twitter all the time and they don’t get thrown in prison for it?

          • abystander says:
            August 16, 2019 at 8:29 pm

            I believe that the “death threats” by random individuals made once on twitter are generally considered venting rather than a credible death threat.

            When they are continually made and become more specific they become credible.

          • John Schilling says:
            August 16, 2019 at 8:59 pm

            It’s only a death threat if, in context, a reasonable person would take it seriously. Twitter being a notoriously non-serious place, one could advance the argument that this is more properly “trash talk”, and even people who own many guns are allowed to engage in trash talk.

            But you’re right, we don’t have lots of people getting arrested for making death threats on Twitter. And “red flag laws” aren’t going to magically result in law enforcement getting collated lists of twitter death threats to act on. So the possible outcomes w/re Twitter and the like would seem to be

            A: Lots of people getting SWATted and/or arrested for trash talk, under circumstances where their counterparts on the other tribe wouldn’t be, or

            B: The creation of a massive and lavishly-funded Twitter Intelligence Teams to identify people who are currently getting away with actual death threats, then instead of prosecuting them like we could do under existing law we “red-flag” them because that’s better because reasons, or

            C: Nothing much at all.

            My bet is nothing much at all. Even among people who intend such laws to do real good seem to mostly expect the good to come from reports by people with F2F contact with the red-flag targets, either family members or mental health professionals.

            But if the plan is to have massively expanded government surveillance for the purpose of dispatching SWAT teams to the homes of people who say the wrong thing on Twitter, then yeah, I can see that going horribly wrong. Can you really not?

            ETA: ninja’d by a bystander. O the embarassment.

        • littleby says:
          August 16, 2019 at 8:46 pm

          More specifically: here’s an article from a week ago, about an indie game developer who received a bunch of death threats: https://thenextweb.com/gaming/2019/08/07/indie-developers-death-threats-ooblets-epic-exclusive/

          Let’s consider the group of people who sent those death threats. What percent of those people do you think have now been arrested and are on trial for committing a felony, and have had their guns taken away?

          If you agree with me that very likely none of those people have had that happen, then I think we have to consider that making death threats may not actually, in practice, be a felony offence.

          • John Schilling says:
            August 16, 2019 at 9:05 pm

            Again, if the existing law isn’t being enforced against the people you think it ought to be, what’s the point of passing a second law that we could but won’t actually bother to use against those people? Or, alternately, what is the reason to believe that the second law will be enforced where the first isn’t?

      • The Nybbler says:
        August 16, 2019 at 8:39 pm

        That arrest is a clear violation of Brandenberg v. Ohio.

        Freedoms of speech and press do not permit a State to forbid advocacy of the use of force or of law violation except where such advocacy is directed to inciting or producing imminent lawless action and is likely to incite or produce such action.

        If the state cannot forbid such advocacy, it certainly cannot punish it by taking guns away. The usual dodge of “that’s not punishment, that’s protection” is always nonsense (and SCOTUS should be ashamed for all the cases upholding it); the state cannot respond to such advocacy with civil commitment either, not yet anyway.

  30. albatross11 says:
    August 14, 2019 at 7:34 pm

    Very interesting essay by Interfluidity about liberalism vs conservativism (really libertarianism) as a function of population density and thus how much of a problem externalities are in daily life. He doesn’t quite hit one other issue, though: one reason to oppose having a lot of regulatory processes is because they’re seldom needed, but an equally-strong one is that you don’t expect them to work very well. It seems to me that a lot of small government conservativism/libertarianism comes down to recognizing that externalities are a serious issue in many places, but still thinking they’re less bad that the likely effects of trying to appoint an Externality Czar overseeing an Externality Bureaucracy to fix the problem.

    Also, the concentrations of power in our society are essentially all urban and are generally culturally very blue. People from the red and gray tribes, and people from rural/exurban areas, can probably expect the Externality Czars and bureaucrats to be from far away and not share their culture or values or outlook, which is another good reason for them to be very skeptical of the value of giving someone the power to regulate those externalities.

    • Clutzy says:
      August 14, 2019 at 9:04 pm

      Are there any homogeneous American cities?

      If not, both the pro-regulatory shift could likely be blamed on the Putnam explanation. You don’t trust your neighbors, they don’t trust you, and there are too many of them for you to learn to trust them in person. So you need extra cops and extra regulations so you dont get shot at or shat on from the 3rd floor.

      • EchoChaos says:
        August 15, 2019 at 6:23 am

        Are there any homogeneous American cities?

        Depends on your definition, I suppose. There are no longer any 90+% white American cities, but there are cities that are over 80% black (Detroit) or white (Salt Lake, Portland).

            Vermont’s largest city is Burlington, which according to Wikipedia is 85% white.

          • EchoChaos says:
            August 15, 2019 at 6:59 am

            @Conrad Honcho

            Yeah, I mean major cities. There are of course smaller cities that are over 90% white.

          • Le Maistre Chat says:
            August 15, 2019 at 8:54 am

            “Portland is 80% white” is kind of misleading, as minority demographics aren’t typical for the US: 4.9% Asian, 2.9% black, 0.9% Native American, 7.4% other or multiracial (I’m aware this doesn’t add up to 100%).

    • Alexander Turok says:
      August 14, 2019 at 9:08 pm

      People who live in dense places correctly perceive that the things their neighbors do blow back upon them. If a neighbor wants to tear-down her single family home and replace it with a midrise apartment building, the typical urbanite doesn’t think “it’s her property, she can do what she wants”. She goes straight to the planning commission to complain about parking and shadows. If someone wants to open up a strip joint, a gun range, even a posh bar in a dense city, urbanites instinctively understand that those choices will have consequences for people other than the entrepreneur and her clients, and demand a regulatory process to balance the external costs (and benefits, at least in theory) against the benefits that business stakeholders would enjoy. This view, that most potential actions have significant repercussions for people who do not voluntarily choose to participate in them, we’ll call externality pessimism.

      The point about parking is correct, though there is an easy solution: charge people for parking. Much of the sense of “regulation is obviously necessary” comes from government policies themselves: if the city of Moscow gives away free bread, Moscow’s people could rightly say that if more people move to Moscow, they’ll get less bread. For urbanites not wanting businesses next door, I’ll give him shooting ranges, but what’s the problem with a posh bar, or even a strip club? If you don’t like lots of people moving around on the street, maybe you shouldn’t be living in a city? I think it’s just that urbanites have a culture of “you need my approval to do that,” independent of any conditions urban life imposes.

      • Hoopyfreud says:
        August 14, 2019 at 9:16 pm

        For urbanites not wanting businesses next door, I’ll give him shooting ranges, but what’s the problem with a posh bar, or even a strip club?

        Ever stepped outside into a pile of vomit? Or been woken up at 2AM by drunken screaming?

        That doesn’t mean I’m on the NIMBY side, but “what externalities?” isn’t a good argument.

        • quanta413 says:
          August 15, 2019 at 9:28 am

          I’ve lived within a block from a bar. There are some nice bars where the externalities are only a little worse than living next to average college students and lower than living next to college students who throw weekend parties. Although if the bar is as big as most restaurants or the buildings share a wall then greatly improved sound insulation may be a reasonable requirement. But the same would be true for a restaurant.

          Requiring people keep the sidewalk out front clean (fine ’em if they don’t) solves the other problem. Cities ought to do that anyways.

          The externalities imposed by drunken people is overrated if the bar is half nice restaurant or family sports bar.

          Granted, there are other bars that create a zone of horrors, but I’m not sure how easy it is to justify those existing pretty much anywhere since the externalities they impose on others are always high.

    • eigenmoon says:
      August 14, 2019 at 10:23 pm

      I don’t buy this: “As poorly governed as our cities currently are, it would be idiocy to argue for less government where in fact the reality of pervasive externalities demands extensive regulation and negotiation.”

      Kowloon Walled City was the most densely populated area on the planet and yet its inhabitants refused to be governed. I’m not saying that they succeeded in creating a pleasant living environment – obviously not. But governments might be so bad that some people would actually prefer to live in a horrible place such as KWC.

      • Hoopyfreud says:
        August 14, 2019 at 11:29 pm

        governments might be so bad that some people would actually prefer to live in a horrible place such as KWC

        Revealed preference suggests that this is not, in fact, typically the case.

        • eigenmoon says:
          August 15, 2019 at 12:17 am

          Where is that government-free zone that people don’t move into, thereby revealing their preferences for government?

        • EchoChaos says:
          August 15, 2019 at 6:03 am

          I’m curious what you mean by this.

          Historically, many a place with less government regulation and interference has experienced dramatic immigration from places with more government regulation and interference.

        • FLWAB says:
          August 15, 2019 at 9:54 am

          Revealed preference suggests that this is not, in fact, typically the case.

          Citation needed? I mean, KWC shows that this is most certainly the case. You had one square block of a city that had no regulations, no police, no governors, and it became the most densely populated area on earth. A population density of over 3,250,000 per square mile. So citation needed here: when given the choice, people showed that they very much preferred to live in a completely lawless society than a regulated one.

          In fact, the main attraction of KWC was the lack of regulations on industry and business. In the beginning it seemed to be mostly criminals, but by the end the cramped city was filled with tiny factories that did not need to comply with safety and labor regulations, and one of it’s primary industries was unlicensed dentistry. You couldn’t meet the licensing requirements in Hong Kong? Set up shop in KWC, people will come in droves for cheap dental work. Sure there were also brothels and drug dens, but there were also fishball and noodle factories, general stores, schools, just about anything you could imagine. Without a government they managed to create a postal system and a crude waste disposal system (although for many years that consisted of gang leaders forcing addicts to clean up the place in exchange for drugs). Most miraculously without any building codes at all they constructed enough residences to house up to 50,000 without the buildings collapsing or getting consumed in an inferno. Have you seen pictures of the place? It looks like a Borg cube!

          For more information, this article has wonderful pictures and details.

          • detroitdan says:
            August 15, 2019 at 6:22 pm

            This seems a classic case of the exception that proves the rule. There was once a portion of a city without government. It’s gone now. There are no places without government. Government is apparently essential to civilization. An alternative was tried where gangs instead of governments ruled, but it didn’t work out in the long run. You can called it revealed preference, or simply cultural evolution.

            Another example is gold as money. No place uses it. Fiat currency, in one form or another, is used everywhere.

            P.S. Thanks for the info and reference. I had no idea this place existed, and it’s fascinating.

          • eigenmoon says:
            August 15, 2019 at 10:47 pm

            @detroitdan
            KWC was bulldozed by the government despite protests of the inhabitants. It has nothing to do with revealed preference.

            > There are no places without government.
            Yes, because governments have expanded anywhere they can. So do mosquitoes and other parasites.

            > Government is apparently essential to civilization.
            Only in the sense that parasites are essential to life.

            > Fiat currency, in one form or another, is used everywhere.
            Fiat money is everywhere because of two reasons: (1) government threats of violence against anybody who doesn’t accept it and (2) it’s bad money. See Gresham’s law: bad money tends to circulate while good money tends to be hoarded.

          • Clutzy says:
            August 16, 2019 at 6:01 am

            eigenmoon was fairly poingnant, but also:

            his seems a classic case of the exception that proves the rule. There was once a portion of a city without government. It’s gone now. There are no places without government. Government is apparently essential to civilization. An alternative was tried where gangs instead of governments ruled, but it didn’t work out in the long run. You can called it revealed preference, or simply cultural evolution.

            Or you can say monopolists like to monopolize. And monopolies of violence are particularly easy to expand.

            Another example is gold as money. No place uses it. Fiat currency, in one form or another, is used everywhere.

            Lots of places have used it. Its always worked fine. It just also happens to impede government monopolies on currency and again, violence.

          • Aftagley says:
            August 16, 2019 at 7:32 am

            @ FLAWB

            o citation needed here: when given the choice, people showed that they very much preferred to live in a completely lawless society than a regulated one.

            You’re ignoring externalities. Hong Kong was an expensive place to live that got a massive influx of Chinese refugees. These refugees often didn’t have the resources to exist in Hong Kong proper so they were forced to go to KWC. If you take your only viable option, you aren’t revealing preference for that option.

            @Eigenmoon

            > Government is apparently essential to civilization.

            Only in the sense that parasites are essential to life.

            Right? Like, life will inevitably result in some parasitic organisms, civilization will inevitably result in governments. Other than your attempted sick burn by comparing governments to parasites, I’m not sure what you’re trying to say here.

            Or you can say monopolists like to monopolize. And monopolies of violence are particularly easy to expand.

            @Clutzy

            Except the triads also had violence. Violence was their whole thing. The triads relied on violence even more than governments. They have to, because they don’t have the respectability (veneer or otherwise) that being a government gives you; force was their only way to ensure they got paid.

            The government didn’t have a monopoly on violence, it just revealed that being a government gives you access to more and better violence than being a coalition of triads does and thus were able to exert their will.

            (Gold Currency) has always worked fine.

            citation needed

          • Matt M says:
            August 16, 2019 at 7:37 am

            Another example is gold as money. No place uses it. Fiat currency, in one form or another, is used everywhere.

          • DavidFriedman says:
            August 16, 2019 at 10:48 am

            I see it as cultural evolution. Gold money and KWC are curiosities that can’t survive in the world as it is today.

            The form of your argument is that of the Whig theory of history, which views it as progress, things changing for the better. To justify that you either need evidence that things have consistently improved, that feudal Europe was better than classical antiquity, absolute monarchy better than feudalism, communism better than late Tzarist Russia, etc., or a mechanism that can be expected to predictably lead to improvement.

            Without one of those, how do you get from “the gold standard was replaced by fiat money” to “fiat money is better than the gold standard”? Are you prepared to make either form of the argument?

          • eigenmoon says:
            August 16, 2019 at 2:05 pm

            @detroitdan
            > Gold money and KWC are curiosities that can’t survive in the world as it is today.
            Maybe. Maybe we’ll soon see Hong Kong itself to be a curiosity that can’t survive. Maybe a Middle Eastern country with oil is a curiosity that can’t remain unbombed. Maybe cultural evolution will throw US into another Civil War.

            But cultural evolution is just Moloch: it’s difficult but not impossible to beat. In a sense, culture is what we’re doing right now. So let’s figure out how not to let government steal our savings via inflating paper money. Let’s figure out what Hong Kong could do to remain independent. Let’s figure out how to pull US from its wars.

            @Aftagley
            > These refugees often didn’t have the resources to exist in Hong Kong proper
            Initially they were refugees, but KWC existed for 50 years. It’s not that the government didn’t offer other apartments to its residents. It’s this:

            When the Kowloon Walled City was torn down by outside forces, many of its residents were dissatisfied with their eviction and not even financial compensation restored the community they left behind. Many, years on, even when fully resettled into the rest of Hong Kong, look back to their days in the Walled City as a “happier time”.

            > civilization will inevitably result in governments
            Yup. But it’s quite different from “Government is apparently essential to civilization”.

          • bzium says:
            August 17, 2019 at 4:18 am

            > This seems a classic case of the exception that proves the rule.

            No, it’s not. An exception cannot “prove” a descriptive rule, i.e. a claim about how the world is. That’s insane moon logic.

            That phrase refers to normative rules. If somebody states an exception to a normative rule, you can infer that the general rule exists.

            Example. You’re applying for a job. The interviewing manager tells you “we have casual Fridays, when it’s okay not to wear a suit.” This is an exception proving the rule that the company has a dress code on other days of the week.

            Now, if instead you talked with someone who happened to visit the office of a company on Friday and they shared their observation that everybody was dressed casually, then that doesn’t in any way demonstrate the company has a dress code. It also doesn’t disprove it, because it could be an exception, but P(dress code) can’t go up.

            The Wikipedia article you linked actually discusses that.

  31. benjdenny says:
    August 14, 2019 at 7:27 pm

    Semi-whiny Semi-Funny Anecdote:

    I’m a secretary who is somewhat overqualified for the basic administrative work I generally have, and who wants to move up in the world. Late last week, I got a link to a video meeting of one of the management process improvement think-groups in my teams chat. I jumped in, and it was explained to me that an Excel calculator was needed to do a certain function, and I was the only person with enough whatever to make it.

    I said sure; it could only make me look good, and enough higher-ups were linked into departments that would use the product and know it came from me that it was good publicity.

    The people with the exact knowledge of what was needed for the calculator are busy people who make something like 2-4x what I do, and did not have the time to give me much guidance on what was needed. Armed with only a general idea of what was needed outside of the desired end result, I got to work.

    The inputs necessary to get to the end result were complex; I had to make several uber-complex nesting if( and if(and statements, one with over fifty entries, to get it dummy-proofed and automatic enough that the rank and file could use it. Eventually I have this super-complex thing that takes a product/service selection, looks at several criteria to see what loans are available on what schedule, spreads out payments, calculates out-of-pocket, all this stuff. It’s referencing like six tables. It takes all day.

    I finally catch one of the bosses long enough to get them to look at it, and it turns out that:

    A. All the departments, save one, that would use the calculator can’t have access to some/most of the information necessary to do the calculations.

    B. The one department that could use the calculator has a custom-built tool that cost tens of thousands of dollars to build that does the same thing mine does, worse, but is already deployed and isn’t worth replacing for the small utility increase mine would give them

    C. It turns out about half of management had one function in mind for the calculator, and the other half another; since I was called into the meeting halfway through there was no way for me to know this and get clarification.

    D. To solve the problem with the inputs all the departments are allowed to have is possible, but involves linear math in a way that can’t be fully automated and involves using Solver; there’s no way to teach ~100 $13 an hour employees to use solver consistently, or indeed even to get solver activated in Excel at once – this general inability to do things is why they needed the calculator in the first place.

    So basically worked real hard all day on above-paygrade stuff for the end result to be me telling a bunch of people something that will sound a lot like “I’m not good enough at my job to do what you want”. I need to learn to force double-checks.

      August 14, 2019 at 8:49 pm

        BUT

        B. Also not important in the way where you pay a lot for them

        So all of their IT/Tech design people are pretty bottom barrel, so stuff happens where they need tools and the people say “can’t be done in house, hire it out” a lot.

      • A Definite Beta Guy says:
        August 15, 2019 at 4:52 am

        Amusing, but, custom-built software tools often with external support. If the Ben Tool breaks, only Ben can fix it, and Ben might be busy doing other things. Also, if Ben leaves, no one can fix the Ben file.

        However, by that point, the Ben file is a business need, so now the business is failing because no one can fix this stupid Excel file.

        I don’t want to crap on Ben, it’s just that this exact scenario has popped up many, many, many times, and the company that had the least amount of these problems had all sorts of custom-built software solutions. These solutions were usually inferior to monkeying around with MS Office for a little while, BUT they were supported and not at serious risk of failure. AND, if they DID fail, the Business Unit could blame someone else for the failure.

        • Nick says:
          August 15, 2019 at 5:48 am

          How much of this comes down to Excel being a ludicrously awful programming environment? If this tool were written in Python in a day, would the same problems hold?

          • EchoChaos says:
            August 15, 2019 at 5:52 am

            That requires an actual developer. Actual developers are expensive and if you aren’t a software shop, you won’t have them available all the time to fix the issues with the software.

            Excel may be a bad programming environment, but it’s a very accessible one.

          • A Definite Beta Guy says:
            August 15, 2019 at 6:18 am

            Zero.
            If the tool were written in Python, the tool would not be written, because your average business employee does not know Python.

            The specific problem is that the End-User has a person who can create their own software solutions, but once that person leaves, the End-User can no longer support those software solutions, because it was dependent on that person. Changing the programming environment isn’t going to change the fundamental problem, which is that you had someone who supported programming that the average office employee cannot support.

            Therefore, anything more complicated than the average Excel file needs to move to the Business Analysts who support that department.

          • J Mann says:
            August 15, 2019 at 6:47 am

            If you have’t read the Story of Mel, you should – it’s topical and hilarious.

          • CatCube says:
            August 15, 2019 at 7:05 am

            To amplify @ADBG, Python won’t improve things, and will probably make it worse. The problem with these kinds of bespoke software scripts/spreadsheets isn’t the calculations, it’s the input and output.

            To use an example that I’ve got kicking around: Using a spreadsheet to calculate the strength of a concrete column. (I have one I created, despite some software packages for the purpose, because I sometimes want to play with things to understand behavior, or to validate the program’s output–“provided as-is”, but I don’t get to provide my work as a licensed professional as-is!)

            It didn’t take very long to create the worksheet, but it’s extremely user-unfriendly. Which doesn’t matter if I’m using it, because I know the guts of every cell and I can tweak them to get specific information I want. It also provides absolutely zero sanity checking of inputs. If I locate steel bars in a nonsense place, the equations programmed into cells will totally still give answers–but they will have no physical meaning, and the user will have no warning whatsoever that this is the case. (Other than knowing that some of these values in the calculation table shouldn’t be negative.)

            Providing a set of rules that would prevent this would be an extremely intricate process, one that will not be any easier in a programming language. The logic of either validating the input or calculating the input won’t differ, just how its worded in the computer. It will also be much harder to actually get the problem into the computer, as I either have to move to a text-based input file, or program a graphical front end. The nice thing about Excel is it’s easy to understand typing in a value to a cell.

            As a matter of fact, I was debating yesterday about converting this spreadsheet into Python or R, because graphical output is a key component to understanding the behavior of structural columns. Excel has very easy ways to create a graphic visualization, but Charts are generally poor–the worst part is that it’s difficult to get axes that use consistent scales so the output isn’t distorted (especially if you change the order of magnitude of output). Recreating the logic in a programming language probably won’t be worth it, so I might just dump the Excel output table to CSV, suck it into R, and plot it there, where you have a lot more control over the graphical output. But again, that’s a very brittle process to hand off to anybody else, and it would require a very significant amount of programming skill to make it robust.

          • Nick says:
            August 15, 2019 at 8:23 am

            @ADBG
            Thanks.

          • AG says:
            August 15, 2019 at 9:40 am

            We’re implementing a system of importing data in various Excel or csv formats to a database, and it involves an insane amount of validations and restricted dropdown list inputs and code that runs every time you click on anything to check inputs and code that runs every time you open the file and code that runs every time you close the file. Keeping inputs clean is definitely a hard problem.

            Currently there’s just two of us in-house that understand some of the guts of these files, while there are other parts that are still only legible to the third party that put these files together.

            And these files that they custom built for us are so fastidious about inputs, that other customers of that third party company have asked about adapting them for their own similar inputs. Because what they had before was much looser and much more prone to user-caused errors.

    • Aapje says:
      August 14, 2019 at 11:40 pm

      @benjdenny

      1. Welcome to the life of a software developer

      2. In your report to management, don’t mention the solver possibility. Managers are like children, who get upset if you tell them that there is something nice that they can’t have. Instead explain that you weren’t made aware that management didn’t yet decide between two different functions and that you looked into one of these, as requested from you. Then explain that this tool requires information from one specific department (finance?), that the other departments don’t have, so that specific department should either be made responsible for offering the tool to other departments, or the other departments should get information from this department.

      Imagine the managers as a pack of rabid dogs. You want them going after each other, while you exist as the impartial expert who gives them different options, that they can fight each other over. Don’t show any weakness and when leaving them, walk slowly backwards, rather than showing your back to them. 😛

    • SamChevre says:
      August 15, 2019 at 5:45 am

      From an Excel geek (I’ve put in my 10,000 hours several times over) – I’ve never seen something that required Solver if you are allowed to use VBA. Solver uses a better algorithm, but a simple loop that iterates the value in a target cell–so start with 0 to 10000 by thousands, find the range where the result crosses the desired outcome, 1000 to 2000 by hundreds, repeat until you are down to cents.

      And welcome to the world of building business tools: no one knows what they need, and if they did they wouldn’t tell you, and there are always really random constraints that no one told you about…

      • benjdenny says:
        August 15, 2019 at 12:35 pm

        It’s not that I”m not allowed to use macros/loops so much as it is that the couple hundred $13 an hour employees this would roll out to would need minimal instructions on enabling content/running macros, and management wants/expects something automatic. I did manage to work out a solution (with help) that automates this, but I don’t know why it works even though I could duplicate the function of it for other non-identical problems.

        • AG says:
          August 15, 2019 at 1:25 pm

          In most cases, “hit the button at the top that says Enable Content, then hit this big button I have on this cover sheet tab that says Push Me” is sufficient. (You don’t even need to mess with Form Controls or whatever, the “button” is usually just a textbox that you assign the macro to.)

          • Aftagley says:
            August 15, 2019 at 1:31 pm

            I once wrote a macro on a spreadsheet that automated a task. Approximately 12 people did this task multiple times a day, and before it was automated it took them somewhere between 15-45 minutes to do. You’d think something that made this mind-numbingly boring task instantaneous would get etched into their brain. This wasn’t even slightly the case.

            Months after I introduced it, I was still getting complaints that the macro had broken from people who day after day continued to forget about the “enable content” warning. I did training, I added a step by step guide, a troubleshooting document and an on-spreadsheet “DID YOU CLICK ENABLE?” textbox. None of it worked. For some reason that banner warning is just invisible to baby boomers.

    • johan_larson says:

      • CatCube says:
        August 14, 2019 at 6:36 pm

        I don’t know how it works on any state level, much less Nevada, but Popehat points out that the maximum sentences for federal crimes often have very little to do with what you’ll actually face:
        https://www.popehat.com/2013/02/05/crime-whale-sushi-sentence-eleventy-million-years/

        Basically, the sentencing guidelines will take heinousness into account, even imperfectly, in setting the range the judge will be able to sentence.

      • anonymousskimmer says:
        August 16, 2019 at 7:53 pm

        [Challenges to fight or acting for another in challenge to fight; use of deadly weapon (NRS 200.450)]

        Unconstitutional law.

        The US (like every other nation) has a long tradition of challenging and fighting.

        The Glucksberg test is law of the land.

        Ergo the right to challenge and duel is a fundamental liberty interest protected by the 14th (and 9th) amendments.

        I have more detailed arguments, but this is enough for an OT. I think an argument for regulating dueling can easily be made (such as forbidding lethal force), but forbidding dueling in total appears to be unconstitutional.

        If then vice president Aaron Burr can do it, so can every other citizen.

        • abystander says:
          August 16, 2019 at 10:20 pm

          I think an argument for regulating dueling can easily be made (such as forbidding lethal force)

          Well use of deadly weapon was mentioned.

          Also I’d like to right to sports stars who abuse their partners scumbags without having to face a duel.

          • anonymousskimmer says:
            August 16, 2019 at 10:50 pm

            Well use of deadly weapon was mentioned.

            Yeah, but the “deadly weapon” part is only one subsection of the law.

            One can always decline a duel. I think a major purpose of the challenge is letting the other party know how angry you are. And oh yeah, the challenged party can also be championed. What do you want to bet that plenty of other sports stars would willingly champion you for calling out an abusive douche?

    • The Nybbler says:
      August 14, 2019 at 6:29 pm

      Mayhem, of course, is the most awesome of those, but the minimum of 2 years rules it out.

      I want something that the other felons will understand (because I assume “what are you in for” is probably a common question), and something that won’t be likely to tick some of them off (so no slavery, child porn, or dogfighting). Also something that makes me look a little dangerous might help — selling a car with a tampered odometer might make me look like a pushover. Not too dangerous though, because I don’t want to have to challenge the prisoner top dog. Either rescuing or aiding in the escape of a misdemeanor prisoner might be good, but since I don’t have details it might get me into trouble. “Coercion” is nice and vague, as is assault with a deadly weapon. They’d be good second choices. But the clear winner is

      Criminal anarchy (NRS 203.115). 1-6 years. Fine is a bit higher than some others. But it sounds really cool.

      Also I’m strongly recommending Civilis gets hired.

    • Lillian says:
      August 14, 2019 at 6:33 pm

      “Aid or conceal child escaped from a State detention facility,” seems right up my alley assuming that by “child” they mean “any legal minor”. I have little respect for the criminal justice system, think a substantial number of things that are criminalized shouldn’t be, and believe teenagers should have more rights than they currently have. Consequently it’s very easy to see myself aiding an adolescent who has escaped from juvie if i thought the charges were bullshit.

    • Grek says:
      August 14, 2019 at 11:25 pm

      Unauthorized absences from prison (NRS 212.095). It’s punishable “under NRS 212.090”, and the maximum punishments are up to 1 year in prison and/or 2000$ in fines.

      I’m sure I had a very good reason for breaking into that prison, pretending to be an inmate and then trying to leave when I was done doing… whatever it was I was doing inside a prison. I just don’t remember what that reason was.

    • Lambert says:
      August 15, 2019 at 3:00 am

      As a non-citizen, is it possible for me to commit treason against the US?

      Or am I presumed to have no loyalty to you ungrateful colonials to betray?

      • zqed says:
        August 15, 2019 at 6:57 am

        As a non-citizen, is it possible for me to commit treason against the US?

        It is very much possible. If Nevada tried to secede from the U.S. that night, and you sold your pocket knife to the NV Army, that would constitute treason against the U.S.

        (IRL the Supreme Court settled this question shortly after the Civil War, in the case of some Britons living down south who made gunpowder for the Confederate army.)

        • Evan Þ says:
          August 15, 2019 at 10:13 am

          Do you have a link to that case? I’m very curious.

          • zqed says:
            August 15, 2019 at 2:50 pm

            Carlisle v. United States

            156: “[…] the claimants here were amenable to the laws of the United States prescribing punishment for treason and for giving aid and comfort to the rebellion. They were, as domiciled aliens in the country prior to the rebellion, under the obligation of fidelity and obedience to the government of the United States. They subsequently took their lot with the insurgents, and would be subject like them to punishment under the laws they violated but for the proclamation of the President of December 25th, 1868. […]”

      • Evan Þ says:
        August 15, 2019 at 10:15 am

        I don’t know of any on-point case about this in the United States, but in Britain, it definitely is possible. William Joyce, better known as Nazi propagandist “Lord Haw-Haw,” was convicted of treason against Britain because he held a British passport and held himself out as a British citizen even though he technically wasn’t.

  34. BBA says:
    August 14, 2019 at 5:13 pm

    As a ’90s kid I watched a lot of the Disney Channel. Back then there weren’t enough episodes of their sitcoms about spunky preteens to fill a 24/7 schedule, so I got to see some of Disney’s more obscure releases, including their live-action movies from the ’50s and ’60s. Most of these were pretty forgettable, but I was clicking around Wikipedia a while back and stumbled onto trivia about one that floored me. It was called The Gnome-Mobile, I remember it had an earworm of a theme song, and it was based on a novel by Upton Sinclair.

    Yes, that Upton Sinclair. He wasn’t all bleak screeds about the dark side of American industry, he also wrote a lighthearted children’s story about gnomes. And Disney made a live-action musical out of it. I’d like to see it screened in a double bill with another Sinclair adaptation, There Will Be Blood, just for the incongruity.

    So now I’m wondering if there are other similarly strange contexts where you find unexpected contributions from cultural figures. It seems to happen with children’s entertainment a lot – George Carlin on Shining Time Station, anyone?

    • Le Maistre Chat says:
      August 14, 2019 at 5:24 pm

It felt incongruous to see Peyton List (the blonde spunky preteen from Jessie et al) as a martial arts bully in Cobra Kai rather than graduating directly to a Marvel movie.

    • DavidFriedman says:
      August 15, 2019 at 7:28 am

      “The Demon Belphegor and His Wife” is a story by Niccolo Machiavelli.

      The demons in Hell discover that almost all of the male spirits condemned to their care blame their wives for their sins. To discover if it is true, they arrange for one of the demons to take human form, along with all human weaknesses, be placed in Italy with a fortune and a train of attendants, marry a human wife, and after ten years fake his death, return to Hell, and report.

      The wife Belphegor ends up with is prouder than Lucifer—a comparison he is in a position to make, having known them both. It goes downhill for him from there.

  36. baconbits9 says:
    August 14, 2019 at 2:14 pm

    I’m currently doing some research for stocks that fit the following criteria.

    1. Stock prices that reflect expected future growth.
    2. High debt loads
    3. Debt maturing in the short term
    4. Easily shortable (ie Tesla is out)

    Any thoughts on stocks that fit the bill would be greatly appreciated.

    • broblawsky says:
      August 14, 2019 at 2:37 pm

      Nothing off the top of the head, but I’d like to compliment you on the courage required for what you have planned. I wish I had it.
