    • Hoopyfreud says:
      August 14, 2019 at 3:08 pm

      Here’s a fast, easy, and bad filter:

      https://finance.yahoo.com/screener/unsaved/6b6135ec-0cfd-4cff-a407-34ba06b8c52b

      E: current ratio was backwards, fixed link, thanks to pqjk2.

      • baconbits9 says:
        August 14, 2019 at 3:17 pm

        Yes, I am going to be running through similar things but they take a fair amount of time to evaluate each company and probably do worse than crowd sourcing from a place like SSC. Also those won’t spur conversations and potential insights.

        • Paul Brinkley says:
          August 14, 2019 at 3:30 pm

          What is the feasibility of dividing the list into sections, and farming them out to SSC volunteers? Sort of a StockTips@Home? The crowd would naturally be small enough to avoid causing market spikes. The main drawback I see is that everyone would do evaluation differently, producing uncomparable results.

          Is it worth teaching SSCers how to do this?

      • pqjk2 says:
        August 14, 2019 at 3:17 pm

        You beat me to it! However, I would recommend using PE ratio rather than PEG as PEG is intended to normalize high- and low- growth companies

        • Hoopyfreud says:
          August 14, 2019 at 3:38 pm

          That seems true. I did say it was a bad filter.

          Do you have any historical data on PEG vs P/E as predictors in a recession? I guess it depends on how previous earnings growth will impact future price deflation. I was just trying to filter for overperformers. Either way, I think a lot of the same companies show up in both lists.

          • pqjk2 says:
            August 15, 2019 at 8:32 am

            I have no specific data or even beliefs on either PEG or P/E as predictors in recession.

            I agree that you would expect a lot of companies to show up on both lists. Thinking about it some more, an even better filter for baconbits’ original question would be high PE and low PEG – this should help filter out companies that are expensive because of non-growth based reasons.

    • pqjk2 says:
      August 14, 2019 at 3:15 pm

      No specific suggestions, but a stock screener could probably help you out with some of these. Flipping through the filters on Yahoo’s stock screener, I might start with the following:

      Criteria 1: High P/E
      Criteria 2: High Total Debt/Equity
      Criteria 3: Low Current ratio or Quick Ratio
      Easily shortable you might need to check manually.
      (hacky workaround – if options trade on the stock, check the price of the ~1 year at-the-money put and call. If the two prices are pretty close, then the stock is most likely cheap/easy to short)

  37. Le Maistre Chat says:
    August 14, 2019 at 1:15 pm

    Sends up the Friedman Signal
    Why do Economics 101 lessons about small-scale societies not match observed facts about such societies? It’s always stuff like “If Farmer Abel can grow grapes much more efficiently than Farmer Banal, Abel will rationally turn all his land to viticulture and sell wine to Banal for wheat even if her land and labor are slightly worse at growing wheat.” Is it simply that violence and religion are outside their knowledge domain, so they ignore how small-scale societies are shaped by raiding and other conflicts over resource use and the role of priests or sacred chiefs rather than direct trade in redistributing food from producers to specialists?

    • Radu Floricica says:
      August 14, 2019 at 1:24 pm

      Because it takes a moderately developed society to have specialists. For most history, even extrem specialists like, for instance, blacksmiths still had their plot of land to tend to.

      I’m not the best to answer why, but I have two guesses:

      – It takes a larger surplus – so a larger population – in order to keep them employed full time. There just isn’t enough blacksmithing to do in a village to feed a family. It takes a town for that.

      – Survival doesn’t like specialization. This goes both ways, btw. A family of specialists survives only until the first drought when everybody realizes that a new sickle is really optional this year while food isn’t. On the other hand, people keep a rather high degree of independence in their household – they like to be able to do a bit of everything, just in case.

      To illustrate exactly how bad specialization is, note that plots of land themselves are as far from it as possible. They’re small and for all intents and purposes randomized. A family might have literally 10 plots in 10 different places. When some cultures fail, at least some of the others don’t.

    • baconbits9 says:
      August 14, 2019 at 2:01 pm

      Don’t they? Almost all large scale agriculture in the US is monoculture with fields and fields of the same crop being managed by a handful of employees.

      • silver_swift says:
        August 15, 2019 at 4:08 am

        The US is not a small-scale society.

        • baconbits9 says:
          August 15, 2019 at 4:38 am

          Society in this context doesnt mean much. Is a small town of a few hundred people in the midwest not small scale?

          • Lambert says:
            August 15, 2019 at 5:25 am

            Society in this context means market/trade network.
            A small town in medieval England consumes most of its production locally.
            A small town in the midwest ships most of its products hundreds of miles to be consumed.

          • baconbits9 says:
            August 15, 2019 at 6:28 am

            The the answer is obvious, you can’t grow mono-culture crops without importing fertilizer, and without a large enough trade network it isn’t going to be feasible in the long run.

    • Matt M says:
      August 14, 2019 at 2:06 pm

      I’ve always felt that comparative advantage, like many economic concepts, is best understood not as a predictive concept but as an explanatory one.

      It’s not that because of comparative advantage, one can “predict” that Farmer X will grow grapes and not wheat. Because in reality, Farmer X, before they plant anything, doesn’t necessarily know what their grape/wheat yields will be. And they certainly don’t know what the grape/wheat yields of all of their various neighbors will be. So they’ll start off diversified. They’ll experiment. They’ll adapt. Conditions will change. They’ll experiment some more. Etc.

      But, if you do happen to notice that Farmer Y is growing grapes exclusively, the answer to “why would he do that?” is almost certainly “because that’s where he believes his comparative advantage lies.” Of course, he may be wrong.

      And as Radu suggests, comparative advantage-based specialization only really works in a large and open market where shortages are rare and unexpected, etc.

      • chrisminor0008 says:
        August 14, 2019 at 6:32 pm

        If your theory explains but can’t predict, it probably doesn’t explain either.

    • Alexander Turok says:
      August 14, 2019 at 2:07 pm

      “It’s always stuff like “If Farmer Abel can grow grapes much more efficiently than Farmer Banal, Abel will rationally turn all his land to viticulture and sell wine to Banal for wheat even if her land and labor are slightly worse at growing wheat.” ”

      Is that really what Econ 101 teaches? It should be teaching to adjust for risk, the highest expected value might be in putting all your eggs in one basket, but the risk of loosing all your eggs means you shouldn’t do so.

    • Phigment says:
      August 14, 2019 at 2:18 pm

      A lot of Economics 101 stuff operates in white-room land where you can sell everything you produce and you can buy everything you want in a timely fashion, and transport and transaction costs are minimized, and you can reasonably trade off production in one thing for production in another thing with minimal trouble.

      That doesn’t make Economics 101 stupid or wrong, it just means you need to remember that the map is not the territory. The world is more complicated than the model.

      If Farmer Abel uses all his land to grow grapes and turns those grapes into wine, can he sell all his wine and buy wheat from Farmer Banal? Maybe. What’s the local wine market like? If he produces 300 gallons of wine a year, but the local quantity demanded is 250, he’s not going to get full price for that wine, and might be better off using some of his land to grow wheat.

      How do the growing seasons for grapes and wheat overlap? Is all of his land equally good at growing both? If a plague of Grape Weevils comes through one year and wipes out all the vineyards, can he recover from that if all he was growing is grapes?

      Lots of people are optimizing for stability and risk avoidance, not for maximum return on investment.

      Also, lots of people just aren’t very efficient, and don’t care. Maybe Abel just likes growing wheat, and gets satisfaction from having his own personal wheat field.

    • ADifferentAnonymous says:
      August 14, 2019 at 3:28 pm

      For the same reason that Physics 101 says that objects gak at the same speed regardless of their weight but bricks obviously fall faster than feathers?

    • John Schilling says:
      August 14, 2019 at 4:13 pm

      Econ 101 strips away all motivations other than maximization of short-term financial profit, and all impediments to a perfect market, for the same reason that Physics 101 strips away friction and viscosity and inelatisticity. You pretty much have to do that to get a teaching exercise that a 101 class can follow,

      Small-scale societies are the ones most likely to be positively dominated by the economic equivalents of friction, viscosity, and so forth. Most economic decisions are being made by individual people with a broad range of idiosyncracies and non-financial motives and without the ability to e.g. remake themselves from wheat farmers to viniculturalists in a season. Small but unavoidable transaction costs that would be almost trivially minimalized in a great mercantile exchange, can consume well over 100% of the profit of small-scale economic interactions and so absolutely and arbitrarily constrain the range of such interactions in ways Econ 101 necessarily ignores.

      Econ 101 can give you insight into things you might have missed about a small-scale economic operation, but its predictive value is much greater for e.g. a large manufacturing corporation.

      • Hoopyfreud says:
        August 14, 2019 at 4:35 pm

        Econ 101 strips away all motivations other than maximization of short-term financial profit

        IME discounting isn’t a 101 thing, and instead you get assumptions about the maximization of infinite-time-horizon profit and the nonexistence of the principal-agent problem.

      • A Definite Beta Guy says:
        August 14, 2019 at 5:31 pm

        Pretty much all this. Plus, if you’re talking about endemic warfare and raiding in small-scale societies…not really an Econ 101 thing.
        There are fields meant to provide realistic depictions about small-scale societies. Econ 101 isn’t one of them.

    • bullseye says:
      August 14, 2019 at 6:27 pm

      The Roman Empire had safe and reliable long-distance transport, and farmers did specialize; each landowner would figure out what was the most profitable thing to grow and then grow lots of that. We see the same thing in modern day. The middle ages did not have safe long-distance transport, so each landowner strove to be as self-sufficient as possible.

      • Lambert says:
        August 15, 2019 at 3:03 am

        As transport in Africa is improving, farmers are switching from subsistance to cash crops, too.

    • Ketil says:
      August 15, 2019 at 1:20 am

      Why is it that Physics 101 teaches how to calculate parabolic trajectories without regard to air resistance or the coriolis effect? (All models are wrong, some models are useful)

      • RalMirrorAd says:
        August 15, 2019 at 4:59 am

        Having taken physics in highschool myself, the 101 version is sometimes taught without the use of calculus, or with the basic formulas pre-derived, or it is taught with calculus but the simplified level where only one variable is being differentiated/integrated. *usually* multivariate calculus is taught later.

        But you need multivariate calculus to start making your physics models less unrealistic.

        I was in a weird situation where I was taking physics that required knowledge of calculus that i didn’t yet posess, and so struggled quite a bit with it.

      • AG says:
        August 15, 2019 at 9:51 am

        Because those models predict enough? Our projectile physics “final” was to fire a ball bearing towards a piece of paper taped on the ground, such that grade of 100 points was centered where students indicated the ball should fall, and grade decreased as a function of distance from that point.
        And lo, it was possible to get a full points grade without including correction factors for air resistance.

        Or my favorite projectile physics demonstration, in which CURIOUS GEORGE HAS ESCAPED AND WE MUST SHOOT HIM WITH A TRANQUILISER DART AS HE FALLS FROM THE ROOF (in which firing a velcro dart triggered the release of a monkey plushie from the ceiling). Again, no air resistance factor in the calculation, but the dart still hit the monkey.

        • acymetric says:
          August 15, 2019 at 10:20 am

          We did the same experiment, but instead of a Velcro dart and a monkey it was a sort of blow gun loaded with a metal ball and the target was a light bulb (suspended by a magnet, the magnet was turned off when the ball passed the end of the barrel).

          • Aftagley says:
            August 15, 2019 at 10:31 am

            You guys had better physics teachers that I did.

          • acymetric says:
            August 15, 2019 at 10:38 am

            My high school physics teacher was easily the best teacher I’ve ever had at any education level. He was well past retirement age, too, he just loved teaching physics (and was damn good at it).

            Every other year he arranged for a “physics” ski trip for the students taking physics. In order to justify it, we had to do a few pages of worksheets involving timing ski runs and calculating various energy/velocity/acceleration/distance related stuff based on our recorded times. And this was a middle-of-the-road public school, not some swanky private school where trips like that are the norm.

            I did get electrocuted once during one of the experiments (involved arcing current from a wall outlet between two nails a few inches apart), but I avoided letting it get reported since I appeared to be fine and it was mostly my fault.

      August 15, 2019 at 4:53 am

      Transaction costs.

  39. Jack Lecter says:
    August 14, 2019 at 12:11 pm

    Hey!

    I just got a dog (pug puppy), and I’m finding the ego psych stuff I’ve learned through here (and from the rats in general) really helpful in understanding her. It provides a framework I hadn’t had before.

    Unfortunately, the internet’s light on canine evo-psych content in general. I found some stuff about dog psychology in general, but I couldn’t shake the feeling that the bottom line was already written, one way or another- (Reading a study on whether dogs actually love humans, funded by purina, I feel like I know what conclusion it’s going to come.)

    So I’m asking here- does anyone have any recs for good, or even non-terrible- work on dog psychology? Or work adjacent enough to dog psychology that I could apply it?

    (To be clear, I don’t mind speculative work in general- it doesn’t have to be terribly rigorous, though that’s always My objection the work I mentioned was less that it lacked rigor than that I’d honestly expect to see pretty much the same article in worlds where the conclusion was true as where the conclusion was false.)

    • Urstoff says:
      August 14, 2019 at 12:19 pm

      I haven’t read Hare & Woods’s The Genius of Dogs, but it seems to be well reviewed. Brian Hare runs the Canine Cognition Center at Duke University; I took my dog to participate in an experiment there, but it turns out Huskies aren’t the most compliant of experimental subjects. I guess recently Hare has developed some sort of dog personality profiling service: https://www.dognition.com/

      For and older-style take of an ethologist, Desmond Morris’s Dogwatching might be worth reading.

    • Phigment says:
      August 14, 2019 at 12:23 pm

      “Don’t Shoot The Dog” by Karen Pryor.

      It’s a book on animal training and behavior modification in general, not a theoretical work on dog psychology, but it’s got a lot of useful and educational insight.

      • Matt M says:
        August 14, 2019 at 2:08 pm

        Can we start including this book on the reading list for various police academies?

    • Le Maistre Chat says:
      August 14, 2019 at 12:30 pm

      I’ll let you know when a specific source comes to mind, but the whole “dog parent” trend is based on evo-psych. The whole “alpha, beta, omega wolf” thing didn’t replicate unless you treated them as synonyms for “parents”, “grown offspring” and “family comedian.” The whole pseudo-evo-psych narrative about men competing to be alpha lest they fall to beta or worse, omega status you hear from Redpill bros? Dominance hierarchies among unrelated canines kinda work like that if you squint, but wolf society is a nuclear family where grown pups hang around as long as they feel like before inevitably (i.e. they’re not eusocial) leaving the pack to find a mate, and one adult pup will initiate most wrestling, which leads to him or her getting roughed up and having lower status in the family (this is stable, as their goofing defuses tension for everyone).
      Basic domestic dog evo-psych is to act like your dog’s parent. There’s no need for straddling them, choke or shock collars, or any sort of dominance behavior more extreme than you’d use with an irrational child. Unless it’s a “dog selective” rescue, they’ll do better with another dog. Keep an eye on their dominance behavior at the dog park, because those dogs aren’t their siblings.
      On that note, another interesting fact about Canis lupus familiarus: we’ve bred them for neoteny and getting along with unrelated housemates like kin, and this makes male dogs only as good of fathers as they are big brothers. If his individual personality includes disinterest in puppies, he’ll do zero parental investment and cause problems when he wants attention from his mate and sees the puppies as in the way.

    • DavidFriedman says:
      August 14, 2019 at 1:01 pm

      You might try Man Meets Dog by Konrad Lorenz, the man who invented ethology.

    • FLWAB says:
      August 14, 2019 at 1:18 pm

      I read Inside of a Dog by Alexandra Horowitz a couple years ago and liked it. It was very informative: I don’t remember how much evo-psych was in it, but it did do a good job of covering the current state of animal psychology research on dogs and what we think we know about how they think.

        Guess the old quip was wrong.

    Books you reread immediately after reading them for the first time. I’ve done this twice in my life:

    Mikhail Bulgakov, “The Master and Margarita”
    Nathaniel Hawthorne, “The House of the Seven Gables”

    Songs that you played over and over and over again after hearing them for the first time. I don’t mean you liked the song and put it in your playlist to listen to later, I mean you played it obsessively six or seven times in a row.

    Duke Ellington, “Portrait of Mahalia Jackson”
    June Tabor & the Oyster Band, “Susie Clelland”
    The Chipettes, “Ring a Ding” (okay, cheating with this one, but I played it for my kids and was immediately hooked)

    I’m not posting this because I’m deathly bored at work or anything.

    • lvlln says:
      August 14, 2019 at 12:33 pm

      Songs that you played over and over and over again after hearing them for the first time. I don’t mean you liked the song and put it in your playlist to listen to later, I mean you played it obsessively six or seven times in a row.

      6 or 7x in a row is considered playing it obsessively? When I was 14 or 15 and watched Neon Genesis Evangelion for the first time, I recall I spent an entire afternoon listening to its opening theme Cruel Angel’s Thesis on loop continuously (while doing other stuff). The song’s about 3 minutes long IIRC, and this was at least 3 hours, so at least 60x in a row.

      More recently, a few years ago I heard I’m Yours sung by Straight No Chaser for the first time and listened to it on loop for at least 10x. This one was less on purpose: I was cooking at the time and also very drunk, and I recall looking at the time and realizing that 20 minutes have passed even though I’d thought I was still listening to the 1st loop of the song, which is impossible because the song’s like 3 minutes long.

      Not a book or song, but I recall back when the anime FLCL was coming out in 2001, finding episodes to download on fileshare programs was kinda hit or miss, so initially I only downloaded the 1st 2 episodes. I immediately rewatched those episodes after watching them the 1st time and rewatched them several times over the next few weeks while acquiring the other 4 episodes. Once I had all 6 episodes, I watched the entire thing through probably at least 30 times over the course of the following summer.

The most I’ve enjoyed a book ever in my life was, by far, The Catcher in the Rye when I was a teenager, but even that I did not re-read for a couple years. I recently re-read the first 20 or 30 pages and suddenly I realized that I now agree with the book’s haters and find Holden unlikeable.

  41. Le Maistre Chat says:
    August 14, 2019 at 11:42 am

    Woke capitalism was inevitable.
    Look at people’s imaginations at the end of the 1960s: they’re dominated by reality and folk culture. Holllywood’s Biblical epic trend is just starting to wind down, ittle girls play with generic dolls, little boys play with toy soldiers and military model kits. Being obsessed with a copyrighted imaginary thing is very low status, as we’ll see with the Star Trek fandom when it’s cancelled.
    Yet it’s in every entertainment corporation’s interest for everyone’s imagination to be dominated by copyrighted worlds they sell. How to achieve that? Support forces that say Christianity, our ancestors, and old stories are “problematic.” As they become hegemonic, everyone will need new fictional settings under fresh copyright they can consume without feeling guilty.
    (Note that this isn’t a full explanation why other types of corporations, like tech or a big shoe manufacturer, must be woke.)

    • broblawsky says:
      August 14, 2019 at 12:01 pm

      So your theory is that “woke capitalism” in the entertainment industry is a way of making people feel guilty about consuming older media? If so, this raises two questions:
      a) If modern media trends have shown us anything, it’s that nostalgia is an extremely powerful force. Why would the entertainment industry throw this away?
      b) People tend to feel attacked when you tell them that the things they love are “problematic”. How would the entertainment industry overcome this if the majority of their customers weren’t already “woke”?

      This fails to have predictive power compared to the more conventional hypothesis: “woke capitalism” becomes dominant when either the majority of capitalists or the majority of their customers feel positive-to-neutral about “wokeness”. This correlates well to the adoption of gay pride in “woke capitalism”, I believe.

      • Le Maistre Chat says:
        August 14, 2019 at 12:18 pm

        So your theory is that “woke capitalism” in the entertainment industry is a way of making people feel guilty about consuming older media? If so, this raises two questions:
        a) If modern media trends have shown us anything, it’s that nostalgia is an extremely powerful force. Why would the entertainment industry throw this away?

        They’re not throwing it away, they’re handing Copyrighted Nostalgic Thing to writer/director-level employees and saying “Remake this with stronger female characters and PoCs.” Sony stood to make a lot more money from New Ghostbusters being a box office success than sales of the still-copyrighted old version. New Star Wars burst onto the scene as a do-over of A New Hope with a strong white girl with no flaws and two PoCs. There’s of course a balance to be struck here: you can’t outright demonize Copyrighted Nostalgic Thing the way you can the Bible or Ovid.

        b) People tend to feel attacked when you tell them that the things they love are “problematic”. How would the entertainment industry overcome this if the majority of their customers weren’t already “woke”?

        A fuller explanation is that the entertainment corporations can’t make people woke by themselves: they have to wait while enough people get a college indoctrination for a strategy of calling everything old “problematic” to work. It was simply never in their interests to support folk culture over copyrighting people’s imaginations, so they didn’t (back when Disney relied on fairy tales, they tried to use IP lawfare to prevent public domain versions of fairy tales they’d done from escaping into non-book sectors like films or dolls).

        This fails to have predictive power compared to the more conventional hypothesis: “woke capitalism” becomes dominant when either the majority of capitalists or the majority of their customers feel positive-to-neutral about “wokeness”.

        That hypothesis doesn’t explain why new entertainment is all woke. If half of people in democratic market economies vote and we generously estimate that the half who don’t vote are 100% feel positive-to-neutral about “wokeness”, capitalism would be leaving 25% of people’s money on the table by never ever appealing to them.

        • broblawsky says:
          August 14, 2019 at 1:40 pm

          They’re not throwing it away, they’re handing Copyrighted Nostalgic Thing to writer/director-level employees and saying “Remake this with stronger female characters and PoCs.” Sony stood to make a lot more money from New Ghostbusters being a box office success than sales of the still-copyrighted old version. New Star Wars burst onto the scene as a do-over of A New Hope with a strong white girl with no flaws and two PoCs. There’s of course a balance to be struck here: you can’t outright demonize Copyrighted Nostalgic Thing the way you can the Bible or Ovid.

          But these companies were producing non-Bible, non-Ovid stuff way, way before Star Wars came out. They didn’t have to make people think that the Bible was “problematic” to produce new, copyrighted material. Why would they have to do that today? The Bible is less important to the average American than it was in 1980, based on church attendance and religious affiliation statistics.

          A fuller explanation is that the entertainment corporations can’t make people woke by themselves: they have to wait while enough people get a college indoctrination for a strategy of calling everything old “problematic” to work. It was simply never in their interests to support folk culture over copyrighting people’s imaginations, so they didn’t (back when Disney relied on fairy tales, they tried to use IP lawfare to prevent public domain versions of fairy tales they’d done from escaping into non-book sectors like films or dolls).

          People decided these things were problematic on their own, without the decision of the Walt Disney Corporation. They didn’t need any “indoctrination”, either.

          That hypothesis doesn’t explain why new entertainment is all woke. If half of people in democratic market economies vote and we generously estimate that the half who don’t vote are 100% feel positive-to-neutral about “wokeness”, capitalism would be leaving 25% of people’s money on the table by never ever appealing to them.

          I’d argue that even a majority of Republicans are OK with “woke” entertainment. Here’s a map of the most streamed shows in the US by state – I would consider the choices of even the Reddest states, like Wyoming (Orange is the New Black) to be fairly “woke”. Maybe most Red Tribe people don’t feel very strongly about the politics of entertainment.

          • Gobbobobble says:
            August 14, 2019 at 2:17 pm

            Maybe most Red Tribe people don’t feel very strongly about the politics of entertainment.

            When it’s what the most talented writers & directors want to work on, you just kinda try to just roll your eyes and tune out the preachy bits

            (which are only for the choir anyway, rarely are they structuring things to actually convert folk. Examples to the contrary would be an interesting topic but nothing’s coming to mind for me right now)

          • Nornagest says:
            August 14, 2019 at 2:55 pm

            I can’t speak for LMC or for Red Tribers, but Orange is the New Black, like Fury Road, is a well-written work with progressive themes that’re tied deeply into the structure of the story. Stories like that don’t strike me as pandering; I might not always agree with the intended message, but those themes, and the casting etc. that supports them, have an artistic purpose and show real thought. They’re neither a cheap nod to topicality, nor a cynical attempt to rope in the millennials, nor a transparent excuse to stir up publicity for yet another reboot or sequel. So, since my problem isn’t so much with the politics of woke media as with its frequent glibness and superficiality, I’m basically fine with them.

          • Trofim_Lysenko says:
            August 14, 2019 at 3:23 pm

            Maybe most Red Tribe people don’t feel very strongly about the politics of entertainment.

            I’m sort of red-gray hybrid, but I’d say it’s less “don’t feel strongly” than “have learned to mostly tune it out”, as Gobboboble noted. Usually I can just shrug and ignore the bits that grate, as long as they don’t become too obnoxious.

            It’s the difference between Fury Road and the Ghostbusters Reboot. Or between China Mieville’s politics informing his world-building in his New Crobuzon books and Charles Stross’ increasingly heavy-handed sneering at America and capitalism in the Laundry Files (which I still quite enjoyed for some time).

          • Le Maistre Chat says:
            August 14, 2019 at 5:40 pm

            @broblawsky:

            But these companies were producing non-Bible, non-Ovid stuff way, way before Star Wars came out. They didn’t have to make people think that the Bible was “problematic” to produce new, copyrighted material.

            Before Star Wars, Hollywood’s equivalents of the modern blockbuster was usually based on history (inc. the Biblical epic, which you can also call myth or folk culture), which is hard to copyright. Go down a level in budget and prestige and you find stuff like The Merry Adventures of Robin Hood, the Greek mythology and 1001 Nights adaptations Ray Harryhausen worked on and Disney’s animated fairy tales.
            None of this lends itself to a horizontally-integrated monopoly where you start by getting kids to pester their parents for official toys from the movie they just saw.

            People decided these things were problematic on their own, without the decision of the Walt Disney Corporation. They didn’t need any “indoctrination”, either.

            Yes and no. They decided these things based on what their college professors told them to believe, which is why college is such a huge predictor of whether people will call themselves progressive when polled. I already said that entertainment corporations don’t have the power to make people hate or feel guilty about old things on their own.

          • Nornagest says:
            August 14, 2019 at 6:04 pm

            Before Star Wars, Hollywood’s equivalents of the modern blockbuster was usually based on history

            I’m not sure how true that is. Jaws basically created the modern blockbuster formula. Before that… well, here’s the top ten grossing movies (inflation-adjusted, from here) released before 1970:

            – Gone with the Wind
            – The Sound of Music
            – The Ten Commandments
            – Doctor Zhivago
            – Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs
            – 101 Dalmations
            – Ben-Hur
            – The Graduate
            – Fantasia
            – Mary Poppins

            There’s two Biblical epics on that list (Ten Commandments and Ben-Hur), and one more that you could loosely call a historical epic (Gone with the Wind), but escapist musicals have as much representation as everything else combined. You could fiddle around with the dates — I chose 1970 pretty arbitrarily — but I don’t think it’d change the outcome much.

          • Le Maistre Chat says:
            August 14, 2019 at 6:12 pm

            But Disney and historical dramas were competing with The Graduate? Wow. Imagine making that much from a present-day personal drama in the Year of Our Lord 2019.

Marvel, though that has a lot to do with Brie Larson I think, since she seems to be something of an activist).

            That said, I think this is effect, not cause. Hollywood leans left, being “woke” is trendy in the social circles of a -lot- of the people producing this material, of course that’s going to be reflected in the way they produce their content. I think “woke capitalism” plays a role too, especially at the higher studio/corporate level, but there are plenty of people who are quite sincere even there.

          • John Schilling says:
            August 15, 2019 at 3:45 pm

            Aladdin and his mother pretty much have to be at least Arab-ish because a wizard from the Maghreb claims to be a blood relative and isn’t laughed out of the house. Which means there’s an Arab immigrant community in that town, which is plausible enough in may places that a premodern Arab would call China, and so possibly many other Arab characters. But it’s at least possible, arguably probable, that the Princess and her father would be anywhere from literal Caucasian through Central Asian to full-blooded Han Chinese – “China” was a big and vaguely-defined place before Marco Polo and for some time afterwards.

            And IIRC one of Burton’s supplemental volumes tracks the story at least to an early 18th-century source that counted it as one (well, a dozen-ish) of the 1001 Nights and predated the “let’s make up anything we can sell to gullible Europeans” period of the tale’s history. Still may be a late and/or marginal addition, of course.

    • INH5 says:
      August 14, 2019 at 12:50 pm

      This seems to miss some important context. For instance, the Hollywood Biblical Epic trend was largely a byproduct of the Hays Code. To put it simply, the censors tended to be a lot less strict on stuff that could be even vaguely plausibly claimed to be “true to scripture.” Once that well runs dry, the incentives for supporting cultural forces that would allow studios to make similarly appealing content in other less played-out settings are obvious.

      Nowadays, Woke Film in the form of race and gender bending and the like seems to be mostly just another gimmick to allow studios to keep churning out remakes and adaptations, because according to the conventional wisdom you need huge special effects budgets to draw people away from Netflix and into theaters, and not even James Cameron is crazy enough to risk huge amounts of money on unknown properties anymore. “Now in live action/with photorealistic CGI!” isn’t selling so well anymore, so they’re trying “Now with better representation!” If that gimmick doesn’t work, then Hollywood will move on to something else like it always does.

    • Hoopyfreud says:
      August 14, 2019 at 2:27 pm

      My dude, for the past couple of (non-integer) threads, you’ve had posts that have come off as just slightly unhinged in the degree of large-scale bad-faith coordination they presuppose exists. I’m not telling you this to be insulting, but because I think you need to be aware of why the ideas you’re talking about are seen as unserious.

      • dick says:
        August 14, 2019 at 3:07 pm

        I didn’t want to speak up but I had a similar reaction.

        ETA some substance: I was re-watching some of the Avengers movies recently (boning up for Endgame, not that that made it make any more sense), and one thing I noticed is that Iron Man was decidedly un-woke rather recently. For example, google “iron man 2 i want one” and try not to cringe as Tony Stark and Pepper Potts do their best Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell impressions.

        To the extent that LMC is seeing an entertainment industry leading the people towards wokeness, I see the exact opposite – an industry that is at worst struggling to keep up and being constantly criticized for it, and at best predicting where the culture will be 2-5 years hence but still looking dated a few years past that.

        I agree that woke capitalism was inevitable, but only in the sense that it was a response to wokeness. If the next generation sees a surge of interest in (let’s say) abandoning technology, then we’ll have luddite-capitalism, I suppose. But what all this has to do with the Bible, Trekkies, etc I did not follow.

        • Le Maistre Chat says:
          August 14, 2019 at 6:00 pm

          ETA some substance: I was re-watching some of the Avengers movies recently (boning up for Endgame, not that that made it make any more sense), and one thing I noticed is that Iron Man was decidedly un-woke rather recently.           This is true. There was a huge change between 2008 and 2013, when the left-wing Iron Man 3 came out. They chose to depict Tony Stark as patriotic, libertarian and a lecher, and it worked for them.

          To the extent that LMC is seeing an entertainment industry leading the people towards wokeness, I see the exact opposite – an industry that is at worst struggling to keep up and being constantly criticized for it, and at best predicting where the culture will be 2-5 years hence but still looking dated a few years past that.

          I agree that woke capitalism was inevitable, but only in the sense that it was a response to wokeness.

          But the fact that elections look like a down-to-the-wire knife fight in a phone booth over culture and economic effects on culture undermines the explanation that capital is running to keep up with a culture that’s all progressives and increasingly more so. Why is entertainment political only ever in one direction? What are Disney, Comcast, AT&T, and Netflix making to get money from the conservative strongholds that make up almost 50% of democratic market economies (Orange is the New Black is, uh, certainly an interesting answer).

          • dick says:
            August 14, 2019 at 9:40 pm

            Why is entertainment political only ever in one direction?

            Because that’s what the market wants, evidently. If you want to convince anyone otherwise, you have a lot more heavy lifting to do. As hoopyfreud said, you’re implying large-scale bad-faith coordination.

          • INH5 says:
            August 15, 2019 at 12:22 am

            What are Disney, Comcast, AT&T, and Netflix making to get money from the conservative strongholds that make up almost 50% of democratic market economies (Orange is the New Black is, uh, certainly an interesting answer).

            First, movie reviewers are very disproportionately woke, and the general audience still trusts the Rotten Tomatoes critic score for the most part, so pandering to that demographic can help your box office as long as the pandering isn’t so bad as to create large amounts of negative word of mouth, as seen with The Last Jedi.

            More generally, when it comes to movies American conservative demographics don’t make up that large a slice of the pie because the biggest market is in China nowadays. But Hollywood still makes some movies for that demo, the most prominent being “heroic” War on Terror movies (Act of Valor, American Sniper, 12 Strong) and movies targeted at a Christian audience (God’s Not Dead, Risen). The fact that these movies are rarely huge blockbusters demonstrates that the specifically “conservative” movie market just isn’t that large, so it isn’t that surprising that the demo gets lumped into “general audiences” most of the time.

            As far as streaming goes, since conservatives tend to be older on average my guess is that Netflix and Hulu do just fine with that demographic by providing the shows and movies that they enjoyed when they were younger. It doesn’t matter to them if making new stuff for that demographic could get more views, because a subscriber is a subscriber. Progressives meanwhile, are more likely to focus on new stuff because they trend younger and, like you said, they’re more likely to consider old stuff to be “problematic.”

            Actual broadcast and cable TV, meanwhile, is outside of news and sports almost nothing but reruns, “blue collar” reality shows, and other programming clearly aimed at older/rural/conservative viewers today. Formerly youth-oriented channels like MTV are barren wastelands that bring to mind Percy Bysshe Shelley’s “Ozymandias.” My guess is that the bulk of the budget for visual entertainment specifically for “conservative” demographics goes into the aforementioned blue collar reality shows, and the “Blue Tribe” hardly even knows about that stuff because most of them don’t bother paying for cable or satellite TV anymore.

            So the changing entertainment technologies may be yet another contributor to the formation of social bubbles.

          • Ketil says:
            August 15, 2019 at 2:40 am

            Why is entertainment political only ever in one direction?

            Maybe it is related to why rich heirs at Yale pretend to be poor and always need to display their wokeness and social awareness? (As linked to by..someone in some previous comments here¹)

            Perhaps successful actors and other Hollywood celebrities, like sons and daughters of successful businessmen come to vast fortunes too easily, or at least without struggling against, idunno, taxation, unions, regulations and general adversity. So they self-identify as “persons of color” or otherwise flaunt some kind of imagined victimhood, or they attack people actually trying to manage a difficult situation (re Richard Gere vs Italy) in order to distance themselves from other elites and enjoy their tremendous privileges without feeling quite so bad about it.

            (Not very charitable, I know)

            ¹ https://palladiummag.com/2019/08/05/the-real-problem-at-yale-is-not-free-speech/

          • lvlln says:
            August 16, 2019 at 8:57 am

            Every action you take and decision you make is political.

            I’ve heard this kind of message for decades, but it was only a few years ago I decided to actually think about it for 1 minute which made me realize just how nonsensical it is.

            Adjectives – like “political” – only have meaning in due to their ability to distinguish things that fit within that category and things that don’t. The adjective “orange” means something only because it allows us to categorize, say, a tangerine as fitting that adjective and, say, a watermelon as not fitting that adjective. If we were to declare something like “every object that exists is orange,” then that doesn’t magically make the watermelon match the color of the tangerine, all it does is redefine “orange” to mean “exists.”

            So the claim “Every action you take and decision you make is political” doesn’t actually make any implications about actions and decisions, all it does is redefine “political” to mean “having to do with actions and decisions any human makes ever.” Which is a largely useless definition; any category that includes both Trump’s negotiations with Kim on nuclear weapons and whether I choose to use my left hand or my right hand when brushing my teeth is one that’s too broad to be of much use.

          • Matt M says:
            August 16, 2019 at 10:03 am

            When everything is political, nothing is.

          • AG says:
            August 16, 2019 at 11:52 am

            The uncharitable remark about American football becoming less of a comfort zone for red tribe is that maybe they should git gud and be recruited to teams on their athletic ability more than black players.

            Kaepernick is just playing Queen Esther, so there’s the additional layer of maybe putting less money and potential political power into a sport, so that athletes have less incentive to play Queen Esther?

          • Matt M says:
            August 16, 2019 at 11:57 am

            Eh, I don’t think the racial mix of the players is really the dominant factor here.

            The NHL is still overwhelmingly white, and yet, it’s going SJ too. Not as hard or as fast as the NFL, but still following the same path.

          • Aftagley says:
            August 16, 2019 at 12:47 pm

            So the claim “Every action you take and decision you make is political” doesn’t actually make any implications about actions and decisions, all it does is redefine “political” to mean “having to do with actions and decisions any human makes ever.” Which is a largely useless definition; any category that includes both Trump’s negotiations with Kim on nuclear weapons and whether I choose to use my left hand or my right hand when brushing my teeth is one that’s too broad to be of much use.

            This is only the case if you think of the world exclusively in binary terms, that stuff is or isn’t orange, is or isn’t political. I think a more useful way to approach the world is to see everything on a spectrum. Think of it this way – both a feather and a brick each have mass, but one can still be heavier than the other. We can say that the brick is heavy and not have it mean that the feather is somehow devoid of the underlying characteristics that make things heavy, just that it doesn’t have enough to trip the mental heuristic that most people have around what it means for something to be heavy.

            Now lets look at your tooth brushing example. You’re right: compared to nuclear arms control your personal oral hygiene habits are decidedly not political. But, there’s just a tiny bit there… You’ll likely brush with your dominant hand: if that’s your right hand, you’ve existed your entire life in a world that’s subtly shaped to accommodate your preference. If you use your left hand, you’ve spent your life using tools and opening doors that were not made with you in mind. That’s a tiny bit political. Is this almost imperceptible amount of politicization completely dwarfed by someone deciding how many world-destroying bombs there should be? Hell yes, but both have the underlying characteristic that results in stuff being political.

            That’s all we mean when we say everything is political – nothing exists that’s devoid of occasionally questionable history, devoid of competing interests, devoid of people who will attempt to use it to increase their power. Some things have it in greater quantities than others, but everything has it.

          • Matt M says:
            August 16, 2019 at 1:21 pm

            Aftagley,

            That’s all well and good. Except that when people say they don’t want football to be politicized, you know damn well what they mean. They mean that they don’t want very political things to be discussed so extensively they detract from the game itself.

            Like, if I told you “Please don’t hit me with something heavy,” it’s obvious to everyone with a functioning brain that what I mean is “You can hit me with a pillow, but not a brick” even though I didn’t give any absolute measures of specificity. If you hit me with a brick, that’s going to be assault, and I don’t think your defense of “Well actually, ‘heavy’ is a relative term, and if you think about it, that brick was quite un-heavy compared to say, an aircraft carrier, so in a sense I honored his request, so I don’t see what he’s complaining about anyway!”

            You know full well that “keep politics out of sports” means “don’t advocate for gun control during the halftime show” (and yes, that’s an actual thing that Bob Costas chose to do) and not “don’t mention that a player is left-handed.”

          • Deiseach says:
            August 18, 2019 at 10:19 am

            Even on the Official Bad Guy Side, there may be people who like sportsball, and think your dismissive class-signalling (“I’m so bigbrained and cultured me, hear me mock the rubes who like games!”) just means you’re a dick who likes jeering at ordinary people with ordinary tastes. (There used to be some particularly objectionable yahoos in my own country, often but not exclusively in the newspaper media, who liked making jokes about “bogball” and so on to signal how Urban Sophisticated Cosmopolite Not One Of You Boggers they were – the kind of people who would have cut their own granny’s throat to be invited to a Jeffrey Epstein party when Epstein was riding high as the guy with the ‘must have’ invites, to put it in an American context).

            Some of those “Welcome, neighbour!” cookies may be poisoned, therefore.

    • baconbits9 says:
      August 14, 2019 at 2:38 pm

      I think it is exatly the opposite, large studios and many execs were functionally conservative. Large scale shifts in taste make their intellectual properties worth less than before, not more, and much of the value of them comes through years of exploitation. Almost all profitable sitcoms make more in syndication than in their original run.

      Wokeness also didn’t start with studios, it wasn’t Captain Marvel followed by people yelling about gender equality in movies, but the other way around, and if Disney gets a flop with their next Star Wars movie they will be on the edge of losing money with the franchise.

    • RalMirrorAd says:
      August 15, 2019 at 6:19 am

      I don’t believe there is necessarily any direct financial motivation to doing what they are doing, at least in terms of wokeness.

      Other people have commented that the absence of originality in film is because you need big audiences to cover the big production budgets. Using familiar IPs is better than taking a risk and hoping something original becomes a hit. 90s Nostalgia also sells obviously. The only exception are individuals who are known to have a sort of midas touch with their ideas and so investors are more open to letting them do original things. (Christopher Nolan comes to mind)

      But the upfront cost of saturating new products with wokeness appears to be fairly high. (Case in point being the reception of TLJ causing a boycott of Solo)

      The people who do saturate the products with Wokeness are, in my opinion, doing it out of genuine conviction. They’re the equivalent of christian films but better funded and more technically competent. A business culture that’s sufficiently captivated can avoid being driven by the profit motive unless and until that business culture changes. Imagine being that one person in a board room for a modern production who argues that film themes should be more reactionary or at least the wokeness should be more subdued so that the product sells more.

      The people who made TLJ probably had a good idea of how well it would go over in China, but they did it anyway because it was the morally correct thing to do.

        Yep. This ties back to Scott’s excellent post about Pride as cultural phenomenon.

          • RalMirrorAd says:
            August 16, 2019 at 7:17 am

            @Acymetric:

            Fans hated the movie and boycotted solo because of it, though Solo was never going to come close to the actual sequels.

            Sw fans are not true reactionaries but good story-telling and reactionary themes often complement eachother [and visa versa] Most people don’t dislike films directly because of wokeness, but wokeness often results in compromising the film’s plot, characters, and universe-logic. Note that not everything that people dislike about TLJ can be attributed to Wokeness. (For example how they handled Snoke)

            We’ll have a rough idea about what kinds of effects we’re dealing with when we compare the change in sales between episodes 8-9 vs. 5-6, though for now we can also see the difference in reception between Solo and Rogue one in terms of parcing the effect of disinterest vs the effect of disgust.

            There’s also the aforementioned aspect of Chinese consumption of SW and the character decisions made in TLJ.

      • LadyJane says:
        August 15, 2019 at 1:45 pm

        But the upfront cost of saturating new products with wokeness appears to be fairly high. (Case in point being the reception of TLJ causing a boycott of Solo)

        99% of the complaints about TLJ had nothing to do with it being “woke.” In fact, I’m not even sure how it counts as a woke movie. Because one of the main characters is a woman and another is Black? Because it has women in positions of power? Because it has broadly anti-authoritarian and anti-conformist and anti-war themes? Those were all true of the original Star Wars movies too. Did people forget about Leia and Padme, or Lando and Mace Windu? Or the fact that the entire prequel trilogy was basically a criticism of American militarism and draconianism, with Darth Vader quoting George W. Bush almost verbatim at one point? Or the fact that Lucas partially based Emperor Palpatine on Richard Nixon?

        I could understand why people might say that The Force Awakens was pandering to SJWs, since Rey was pretty much the epitome of a Strong Independent Female With No Flaws (as opposed to The Last Jedi, where she’s actually portrayed in a more nuanced and human light). But people complained about that one a lot less than TLJ, which suggests that “wokeness” isn’t really the key issue here.

To be clear, the typical star wars fan probably doesn’t care about the interracial couple aspect, only the fact that the sub-plot served no purpose. Whereas chinese audiences probably did.

          3 has no tennable connection to wokeness as far as i can see, just Ryan Johnson playing gotcha with the audience.

I think if a film had been made this fashion (i.e. rushed and without any pre-planning) without any hint of wokeness it would have been poorly received.

            The fact that TLJ did substantially worse than TFA in china is indisputable, but given the difficulty in actually sampling public opinion i could be wrong.

            The only concrete piece of evidence i could find was the chinese state media altering TFA poster in such a way as to make Finn substantially less prominent. Given that western media tends to be more woke than the average joe, it’s possible that the chinese government and state media is more anti-woke than the chinese people. It’s also possible the marketing decision was better calibrated to chinese audiences than we in the west would care to believe, in which case my original theory about the chinese not being particularly fond of African characters stands.

            https://www.cnn.com/2015/12/08/asia/star-wars-china-racist-poster/index.html

            I recall a few articles talking about “The real reason TLJ flopped in China” and none of them mentioned the racial aspect [only going as far as to say that the actors were not familiar and not very attractive by hollywood standards] that’s a point against me, but at the time it felt to me like western media outlets would never hint towards foreigners having such racial views, and putting forward every possibility but the possibility of chinese racism felt like damage control.

    • albatross11 says:
      August 15, 2019 at 8:14 am

      I think the basic error you’re making is:

      a. Observe some change in the world.
      b. Note that this change would be beneficial to some powerful group or interest.
      c. Infer that the change is due to that powerful group or interest.

      Most of the time, the changes are due to a whole bunch of different forces, and the powerful group benefitting from them contributes at most a small fraction of the forces. If you want to infer (c), you need to find why the change is entirely or mostly due to that powerful group’s actions.

      This error is really common in political/social/culture war discussions. ISTM that you almost can’t find a discussion of patriarchy or white supremacy/white privilege that doesn’t invoke it.

      • DavidFriedman says:
        August 15, 2019 at 9:45 am

        It even has a name: Cui Bono.

    • viVI_IViv says:
      August 15, 2019 at 8:34 am

      Yet it’s in every entertainment corporation’s interest for everyone’s imagination to be dominated by copyrighted worlds they sell.

      Yes, but I don’t see how it relates to wokeness.

      There are many more works with Batman rather than Zorro, even though Batman is essentially a copyrighted ripoff of Zorro. (It’s even alluded to in canon: in Frank Miller’s version of Batman’s origin story, Bruce Wayne’s parents being killed right after the family went to watch a Zorro movie or theater play.)

      Yet Batman isn’t any more woke than Zorro. Woke entertainment is a much more recent phenomenon than copyrighted franchises.

    • AG says:
      August 15, 2019 at 10:07 am

      Do you count Las Vegas leading the charge on racial integration to be woke capitalism?

      That’s traditionally been the left defense of capitalism, that the drive to make money from everyone and anyone means a level of inevitable inclusivity that other gatekeepers cannot win against in the long term.

      In this sense, the current mitigating force against woke capitalism is globalized capitalism, because that inclusivity has extended to less woke cultures, most notably China.

      But yes, so locally, woke capitalism was inevitable.

          • AG says:
            August 15, 2019 at 1:43 pm

            What doesn’t make sense is a market economy where entertainment corporations make niche media for black people but Red-white people have no representation except as evil buffoons.

            This is most definitely not happening. You are Chinese Robber fallacy-ing woke media. If you aren’t seeing how much media is out there that is still all straight white people all the time, that’s on you.

          • albatross11 says:
            August 15, 2019 at 3:07 pm

            What I think is true here:

            a. There are many movies and TV shows and plays derived from source works where the original characters and the actors playing them are different races, nationalities, genders, sexual identities, sexual orientations, etc.

            b. Most of the time, this doesn’t matter a bit–it doesn’t really affect the story one way or another. Swapping out a black cop for a white one in the next police procedural you see probably doesn’t matter. If you did an adaptation of _A Fire Upon the Deep_ and cast Ravna as a black woman and Pham Nuwen as a tall blonde guy, it wouldn’t really change anything about the story.

            c. Sometimes, it messes with the story. If someone does an Easy Rawlins film adaptation and changes Easy to a white guy, it’s going to completely scramble the story. Or if someone adapts the Change books to film and changes Tiphaine’s character to a straight man, that’s going to radically change a lot about her character that impacts the story.

            d. It’s moderately common for there to be some kind of outcry when someone’s race, sex, sexual orientation, etc. is changed from the source material to the film/stage adaptation. As best I can tell, most of this is driven by people trying to ride on the coat-tails of some big media name to get clicks, or by actors working the refs in hopes of getting more roles reserved for themselves in the future.

            e. When this happens, about 99% of the respectable voices in our society take it seriously when the original character was nonwhite/female and is played by a white actor, and dismiss the complaint as racism from the unsophisticated when the original character was white/straight/male and the actor is nonwhite/female.

            f. This has become CW stuff, so that this reaction is kind-of automatic. Which means you get the “shut up, you dumbass deplorable,” even in the cases where the complaint makes sense.

            In the wheel of time stories, for example, there are a bunch of storyline and world-building reasons why people should ethnically look a certain way, and changing that somewhat messes up the story. Not in an unfixable way, but at least in a way that weakens some of the storytelling and leaves the audience needing to ignore some apparent contradictions. I mean, you can do an adaptation of Huck Finn where Jim’s Asian and Huck is black if you like, and it might even be pretty good, but it’s also going to be kinda confusing for the audience and probably harder to maintain their willing suspension of disbelief.

          • albatross11 says:
            August 15, 2019 at 3:19 pm

            I think there are other forces besides public demand going on–including the fact that the consensus morality/view of the world among people in media is *very* different from that of most of their customers.

  42. Milo Minderbinder says:
    August 14, 2019 at 11:07 am

    Reading the recent Less Wrong write up of Moral Mazes alongside the Iliad led to a somewhat disturbing thought. The ersatz morality of corporate management is strikingly similar to Bronze Age social mores. I’m drawing from the Secret of Our Success/ The Horse, the Wheel, and Language/ Against the Grain (by James Scott of Seeing Like a State).

    Examples:

    The importance of lineage/hierarchy versus individual achievement in assigning credit/failure

    Culture=Law=Custom in a way that wouldn’t fly in civil society. “This is the way we’ve always done it” being much more valid as a reason for particular action, and the line between “what we do” and “what must be done” is negligible.

    A lack of hostile intent in (initiating) intergroup competition. I do not mean that the competition itself is not violent, rather, that avarice is the driving force. That Ilion has riches, or that Pepsi has particular market share in some region, is sufficient in and of itself to justify aggressive action to expropriate the resources of the other. Essentially, corporate competition has access to “barbaric” casus belli, wherein wealth in some market sector drives competition in that sector.

    The very size of the relevant social units: Most corporate hierarchies are, from the perspective of the individual, more legible with regard to chains of authority and relation than civil society as a whole. The size of one’s employer is more akin to early pre-state and early states (a few dozen to several thousand for most).

    …..

    That’s all pretty obvious. The interesting thing is when one combines this with the decline of broader community participation. If people’s incentives in corporate space lead to Bronze Age moral structures, then naturally the constraint on such morality would be the incentives from other aspects of one’s life. If, as it is put by a manager in MM “What is right in the corporation is not what is right in a man’s home or in his church.” then the desire to present a broadly pro-social suite of characteristics would limit one’s ability to fully adopt the “necessary” (i.e., retrograde) morality required to succeed in the corporate world. If, however, one’s social life is consumed almost entirely by one’s job, or if one lacks the additional social supports, then it seems that following the local incentives would lead to someone who more or less possesses Bronze Age morality: fierce in-group loyalty, “blind” obeisance to custom (per SoOS, not necessarily a bad thing), a lack of concern (or even a conception) of individual rights, and a complete lack of empathy for outgroups. I’m wondering if this phenomena might be at least a part of the falling out of favor for liberal morality. Namely, fewer people are living in civil society, so their incentives are not to act in such a way that promotes civil society.

    • Nornagest says:

    • Erusian says:
      August 14, 2019 at 12:07 pm

      I might suggest you’re reading the Iliad somewhat uncritically if you think you’re supposed to consider the characters to be Bronze Age moral examples.

      I also don’t see strong evidence for most of these as Homeric values. The importance of lineage? They put importance primarily based on personal qualities (who’s clever/strong/whatever) and secondarily on how many ships they brought. Yes, in general they’re all nobles, but they’re not acting in a strict predetermined hierarchy.

      Culture=Law=Custom? What? “This is how we’ve always done it”? Done what? Avenged wives getting kidnapped? Kept their word? They didn’t even really do that. Agamemnon had to force many of them into coming and a repeated theme is herding cats. Sure, they have culture and rituals they follow but they do new ones when the ones they have don’t work.

      A lack of hostile intent? Blithe competition for resources? What? They don’t go around sacking everyone just because they’re there. They have a specific grudge with Troy.

      As for size, the smallest contingent Homer mentions is three to four hundred people. 98% of businesses have less than a hundred people. 89% have less than 20. You’re overestimating the size of most businesses.

      • Milo Minderbinder says:
        August 14, 2019 at 12:19 pm

        Yes, they’re at Troy for a specific reason, but when Achilles boasts of sacking 11 cities, and when Nestor claims “Back in my day, we only needed 6 ships to steal 50 droves of cattle!” (to an approving, reproached response by Agamemnon), there wasn’t any reason besides that they had a raiding economy.

        Agamemnon forced them by specifically appealing to their duty. A society’s morals and the morality of individual members will of course diverge. They were bound by oath and custom, and this was frequently appealed to to rouse warriors out of their “selfish” desire for safety.

        My takeaways were mainly from the books on the Bronze Age, it was just the specific claim of “immorality” regarding behavior in corporate space that intrigued me, and seeing these particular “values” celebrated in the Iliad is what brought it together.

        Also, whether or not the characters were all intended to be moral examples, their archetypes (Seeker of worldly wealth, seeker of eternal glory, dharma hero, guy thrown into this mess whose gonna get through no matter what, etc.) are hugely influential on human behavior. Famously, Napoleon was an avid reader of the classics, and explicitly cites Achilles’ motivation as superior to Agamemnon’s

        • JPNunez says:
          August 14, 2019 at 12:31 pm

          Gotta remember that the Iliad is a tragedy; Achilles had the choice for glory or a peaceful life, and chose glory, and got that glory by avenging the death of his best friend. Similarly, Troy falls because of the imprudence and lack of wisdom of Paris. The Iliad is very critical of the values of Agamemnon, Achilles, Patroclus, Paris and others. Nestor is the equivalent of Grandpa Simpson, except that he was charming and everyone humored him.

          The lack of good values is what made Paris doom his city, but following their values drove the greeks toward Troy and to death for many of them, and being missing from home to others.

          • Milo Minderbinder says:
            August 14, 2019 at 12:42 pm

            Wait, I think what’s being missed here is potential disconnect between the original Bronze Age (Mycenaean, palatial states) morality (as shown by the actions of the characters) and later Homeric (Greek dark age, proto-city states) interpretation of said morality. Like, some guy in 1000 BCE who was telling the oral Iliad may not have seen the tragedy in certain elements (or the original telling may lack the elements altogether).

            I’m not saying Homer thought these actions were laudable, but that the Iliad is a vehicle by which ancient morality is preserved for present analysis.

          • JPNunez says:
            August 14, 2019 at 1:21 pm

            I think the Iliad was composed like 500 or 1000 years after the point when Troy existed and the war could even happen. I suspect the central plot point of the Iliad -a guy avenging his friend in the middle of a siege on a doomed city- would look tragic even in the initial versions of the poems; sure, there are some characters who look like value models, some of the time (Diomedes seems like an all around good guy, Hector is most of the time shown in a positive light, all the greeks act heroic once they see Patroclus dead and want to carry his body back to Achilles, Achilles granting Priam a truce for Hector’s funerals and also the body of the guy) but largely I doubt listeners left the Iliad recitals wanting to create a compact of princes protecting some random marriage or go sacking other islands for decades.

            Even back then most people would have sided with Achilles over Agamemnon; Napoleon is not really breaking tradition there.

          • Protagoras says:
            August 14, 2019 at 1:39 pm

            Plato’s criticism of Homer makes it clear that in his view, exposure to Iliad made all the little Greek boys want to be Achilles. Probably he exaggerated, but this seems to have been true in at least some cases (most notoriously Alexander the Great). And in any event, he surely had a better idea of how the stories were heard in his time than we do.

          • JPNunez says:
            August 15, 2019 at 11:52 am

            Plato was probably a weirdo, tho.

          • RalMirrorAd says:
            August 16, 2019 at 8:00 am

            Plato’s account makes a bit of sense if you think of a male child as not having a solid concept of cause-effect, and identifying with the strongest character in the series.

        • Erusian says:
          August 14, 2019 at 12:45 pm

          when Achilles boasts of sacking 11 cities,

          As I recall, he brags of sacking twelve cities near Troy and subject/allied to Troy. Enemy cities.

          when Nestor claims “Back in my day, we only needed 6 ships to steal 50 droves of cattle!” (to an approving, reproached response by Agamemnon), there wasn’t any reason besides that they had a raiding economy.

          Nestor’s raid is explicitly set up as saving the desperate, poor Pylians who had been ravaged by a demigod. Despite this, he chose a target he felt he had a cassus belli against (or at least invented one). He claimed his target had raided them in the past to steal from them when they were weak and his raid was vengeance. He explicitly uses the language of debt and repayment.

          • Milo Minderbinder says:
            August 14, 2019 at 1:01 pm

            Right. But that’s my point. These cyclical raids for metals/women/cattle were a normal part of the Mycenaean economy. They once raided us, so our actions are justified. Like Roman justification of cruelties against the Gauls because of the prior Gallic sack of Rome. The morality is fitted to the dominant economic mode, that is, people’s morality aligns with that which will allow them social success, and in Mycenaean Greece morality aligned to favor a raiding economy. My original point was that people, having less interaction with positive-sum civil society and more with (not necessarily in reality, but perceptually) zero-sum corporate society would revert to a morality which celebrated such actions.

            “Their ancestors wronged us, so present atrocities are justified” is precisely the kind of Bronze Age morality I’m talking about.

            edit: I can’t seem to respond further down the chain, but I never mentioned De Bello Gallico. I’ve read and was told in college (been a few years, can’t remember names of texts) that Roman politicians would use the historical sack of Rome as a way to rally public support for military excursions in the region generally. Also, went back and re-read Nestor’s description of the raid, my translation is ambiguous with the passage of time, I may have overestimated the span between Elis initiating hostilities and Pylus’ response.

          • Erusian says:
            August 14, 2019 at 1:18 pm

            “Their ancestors wronged us, so present atrocities are justified” is precisely the kind of Bronze Age morality I’m talking about.

            It wasn’t that distant. Nestor claims they raided them immediately before. The narrative is, “Hercules attacked us, we were weak so they raided us, then we were poor and weak. So I raided them and took enough for us to live well.”

            Likewise, you appear to not understand the Roman justification for war with the Gauls. I don’t recall Julius Caesar mentioning the sack of Rome at any point in De Bello Gallico. It certainly wasn’t his reason for war.

            The morality is fitted to the dominant economic mode, that is, people’s morality aligns with that which will allow them social success, and in Mycenaean Greece morality aligned to favor a raiding economy. My original point was that people, having less interaction with positive-sum civil society and more with (not necessarily in reality, but perceptually) zero-sum corporate society would revert to a morality which celebrated such actions.

            As I am pointing out, you aren’t repeating what justifications they actually gave. And you’re shaping their actions to fit your narrative by adding or subtracting relevant details. This doesn’t invalidate the general theory but it does remove the evidence you put forward.

    • viVI_IViv says:
      August 15, 2019 at 8:43 am

      Reading the recent Less Wrong write up of Moral Mazes alongside the Iliad led to a somewhat disturbing thought. The ersatz morality of corporate management is strikingly similar to Bronze Age social mores.

      I’m not sure what conterfactual scenario you’re imagining here. Humans are naturally competitive, they like to establish dominance hierarchies and hoard resources. The difference between the Bronze Age and the present age is that the CEO of Pepsi doesn’t lead his employees to sack the headquarters of Coca Cola and burn it to the ground.

      You can’t turn humans into eusocial ants. Communism was an attempt to do that and look how it turned out.

  • Advertisements

  • Seattle Anxiety Specialists are a therapy practice helping people overcome anxiety and related mental health issues (eg GAD, OCD, PTSD) through evidence based interventions and self-exploration. Check out their free anti-anxiety guide here

    .

    The Charter Cities Institute is working on ways governments can set up special zones with unique legal institutions. Learn more about how this could help tackle problems from global poverty to climate change.

    Substack is a blogging site that helps writers earn money and readers discover articles they'll like.

    Support Slate Star Codex on Patreon. I have a day job and SSC gets free hosting, so don't feel pressured to contribute. But extra cash helps pay for contest prizes, meetup expenses, and me spending extra time blogging instead of working.

    Metaculus is a platform for generating crowd-sourced predictions about the future, especially science and technology. If you're interested in testing yourself and contributing to their project, check out their questions page

    80,000 Hours researches different problems and professions to help you figure out how to do as much good as possible. Their free career guide show you how to choose a career that's fulfilling and maximises your contribution to solving the world's most pressing problems.

    Dr. Laura Baur is a psychiatrist with interests in literature review, reproductive psychiatry, and relational psychotherapy; see her website for more. Note that due to conflict of interest she doesn't treat people in the NYC rationalist social scene.

    B4X is a free and open source developer tool that allows users to write apps for Android, iOS, and more.

    MealSquares is a "nutritionally complete" food that contains a balanced diet worth of nutrients in a few tasty easily measurable units. Think Soylent, except zero preparation, made with natural ingredients, and looks/tastes a lot like an ordinary scone.

    Giving What We Can is a charitable movement promoting giving some of your money to the developing world or other worthy causes. If you're interested in this, consider taking their Pledge as a formal and public declaration of intent.

    The COVID-19 Forecasting Project at the University of Oxford is making advanced pandemic simulations of 150+ countries available to the public, and also offer pro-bono forecasting services to decision-makers.

    Jane Street is a quantitative trading firm with a focus on technology and collaborative problem solving. We're always hiring talented programmers, traders, and researchers and have internships and fulltime positions in New York, London, and Hong Kong. No background in finance required.

    Altruisto is a browser extension so that when you shop online, a portion of the money you pay goes to effective charities (no extra cost to you). Just install an extension and when you buy something, people in poverty will get medicines, bed nets, or financial aid.

    Norwegian founders with an international team on a mission to offer the equivalent of a Norwegian social safety net globally available as a membership. Currently offering travel medical insurance for nomads, and global health insurance for remote teams.

    AISafety.com hosts a Skype reading group Wednesdays at 19:45 UTC, reading new and old articles on different aspects of AI Safety. We start with a presentation of a summary of the article, and then discuss in a friendly atmosphere.

    The Effective Altruism newsletter provides monthly updates on the highest-impact ways to do good and help others.

    Beeminder's an evidence-based willpower augmention tool that collects quantifiable data about your life, then helps you organize it into commitment mechanisms so you can keep resolutions. They've also got a blog about what they're doing here
